PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft operational standards for superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Gold Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the welfare of many employees and their families depends upon a healthy, expanding gold mining industry;
(ii) the success of many small businesses in gold mining towns also depends upon the continued profitability of gold mining and prospecting operations;

(iii) the Federal Government's proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining and prospecting represents a threat to the profitability of these industries and will therefore cause widespread unemployment and depression throughout the whole gold mining industry.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Government to reject any proposal to introduce a tax on gold mining or prospecting thereby ensuring that the spectacular growth of the industry over recent years is continued.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia and
(2) Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium 137 and Caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. Parliament House Canberra-A.C.T.

We the undersigned petitioners of the State of Western Australia request you, as our representatives responsible for the overview of the introduction of new Legislation, to vote against the Bill of Rights currently before the Senate for the following reasons;
The Bill will erode State and Local Government rights.
The Bill is hostile to the traditional family which is paramount in our Christian way of life.
The Bill erodes parental authority in the family.

The Bill does not give parents the right to send their children to the school of their choice, and could be used against religious schools who only recruit teachers who meet the schools religious and moral criteria.

The Bill in certain cases denies the right to legal representation and therefore is contrary to natural justice. The Bill is silent on the right to own property which is basic to the Australian way of life.
The Bill denies the right to life to those who are not `Natural Persons'.
The Bill recognises the right of criminals at the expense of their victims.
We therefore pray that you as our representatives will take into account our concerns as outlined above and see fit to vote against the Bill aforementioned.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Honourable members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 budget.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) The Agreement between the United States of America and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap terminates on 19 October 1986.
(2) In the event of war between the United States and the Soviet Union, access by the United States to Pine Gap's facilities makes it a probable nuclear target.
(3) Access by all nations to Pine Gap's capacity to monitor and verify compliance with existing and future nuclear limitations treaties could contribute to world peace and security.
(4) The people of Australia are entitled to be consulted, through their representatives in Parliament, on any extension or modification of the Agreement affecting their lives, security and welfare.
And your petitioners humbly pray that:
(1) The Agreement between the United States and Australia concerning the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap not be extended beyond October 1986.

(2) Public discussion and inquiry be instituted into the feasibility of negotiating a new agreement with the United Nations during the International Year of Peace offering the verification facilities of the Pine Gap base to all nations.
(3) Any agreement concerning the future use of Pine Gap be referred to Parliament for ratification.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Sir John Carrick (from 14 citizens) and Robertson (from 40 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australian Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill:
1. Offer nothing more than is already available under law,
2. deny some Human Rights and do not include others,
3. give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and
4. could cause far more damage than they could possibly cure.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Senate should: completely reject the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest consideration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Chernobyl Nuclear Accident
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That following the Chernobyl nuclear disaster of 26th April 1986, the Soviet Union has not yet adequately explained to its citizens or those of the Soviet-occupied Baltic States, Ukraine and other areas affected by the radiation fall-out the potential short-term and long-term health hazards and the available modes of prevention or reduction of radiation poisoning. Neither have the appropriate medicines for substitution therapies to minimise bodily accumulation of radioactive elements been adequately provided.

2. That the Soviet Union operates many nuclear power stations without the elementary structural safeguards against radioactive spillage regarded as mandatory in the West. Of particular concern is the safety of the largest Soviet nuclear power station at Ignalina in Soviet occupied Lithuania, of similar design to Chernobyl, which already has a record of operational problems. Radioactive spillage at Ignalina would quickly contaminate the whole of Latvia, Lithuania as well as vast areas of Europe.
We request that the Australian Government will,
1. Through the World Health Organisation, provide medical aid and broadcast medical information to the victims of radiation exposure following the Chernobyl disaster.
2. Through the United nations Organisation request the Soviet Union,
(a) to close down all nuclear power stations similar to Chernobyl till protective structures are built.
(b) permit international inspection of such safety structures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that in the International Year of Peace, young Australians face an uncertain future due to:
1. a continuing arms race between the super-powers which threatens to extend into outer space;
2. military expenditure continuing at ridiculously high levels;
3. continuing testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons;
Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament to do everything possible to make our future more certain, by:
1. encouraging peaceful dialogue through diplomatic channels as a means of solving issues;
2. persuading all developed countries to spend less on armaments, and more on basic needs like food, health, shelter and education for all people of the world;
3. promoting the extension of agreements to reduce testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: African National Congress
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Parliament of Australia assembled. The petitioners of certain citizens of Australia draw the attention of the House-

To information that-a known terrorist organisation is operating from Australia under the name of African National Congress, with quasi diplomatic status, and with the support of the Australian Government.
Your petitioners therefore request that: The Australian Government will take appropriate action to-
1. Withdraw Government support for this organisation;
2. Expel any officials of this terrorist organisation resident in Australia or visiting under visa conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister re-presenting the Prime Minister to a criticism by the Treasurer of Mr John Elliott's comment last week on the unfavourable investment climate which currently exists in Australia, a situation which is reflected in the Government's own Budget forecast of a further drop in private business investment over the course of this financial year. I ask the Minister whether he noted yesterday's comments by Mr Charles Fitzgibbon about the investment outlook in Australia when he said that there was no way at present that he would put his money in Australian companies. He said:

QUESTION.PARA: People will put money into a concern when they consider that they will get from that enterprise a return for their money which equates what they can get somewhere else.

Does the Minister agree that, while the Government maintains its present high interest rate policy, investment in the manufacturing industry, which is essential for Australia's economic recovery, will not take place? How long does the Government intend to maintain the high interest rate, high tax regime which deters investment and which has produced the situation referred to by both Mr Elliott and Mr Fitzgibbon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen Charlie Fitzgibbon's comment about his personal investment predilections. I will certainly look them up, though, because I have a high regard for what he says. I think he is a very genuine Australian concerned about the fundamental issues confronting this country. I will certainly read his view which, in my opinion, is quite distinct from the view which was expressed by Mr Elliott on Thursday last week, which was totally inconsistent with views which Mr Elliott put in New York a fortnight before and at a seminar in which I participated six weeks before that. In saying that, I do not detract from the validity or the sincerity of any of those people in putting those opinions. I just say that they are very different from opinions which have been put in previous forums and on previous occasions. I will certainly look at what Mr Fitzgibbon said.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney referred to the investment outlook as predicted in the Budget statements. That is not an encouraging investment outlook. I do not have with me the figures in respect of manufacturing investment-those which are most recently available-but last year's figures for manufacturing investment were considerably better than the investment pattern as a whole. I will certainly get those figures. The implications of the last part of the honourable senator's question were that investment had been retarded by high interest rates and taxation policies. That is a matter of considerable argument and I do not want to debate the issue here in answering a question. But I have conceded on previous occasions in the Senate that I thought that the interest rate regime was more difficult for small businesses than larger businesses. It has probably had a greater impact on investment in that area than on larger businesses which, by and large, have had record profits out of which investments have been made and can be made. I do not see much point in debating the taxation part of the honourable senator's question at Question Time. It has been the subject of long, tedious and boring debates in the Senate over the last week or two, and I do not think I have anything to add in respect of this answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education seen the article by Professor Don Aitkin in last Friday's Age in which he points to the need for universities to be accountable to the community? Does the Minister agree with the professor on the need for applied as well as pure research to be carried out in universities? How does the Minister see universities becoming more involved in the community and how could they make the community more aware of their work? Does the Minister agree with the assessment of universities by Professor Aitkin and, in particular, his claim for the importance for Australia of an educated and skilled community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the opportunity to read Professor Aitkin's article and found myself in general agreement with much of it. I would not like to put the seal of approval on every comment he made. But certainly Professor Aitkin, like an increasing number of leaders in our academic community, is aware that universities are publicly supported and, therefore, the community needs and wants to know more about the work that is done within them. There has been a tradition among universities in Australia and to an extent in other countries to see themselves apart from the community and to feel no need to communicate with the community generally as to what they are doing. I do not think this has been in the interests of universities and, certainly in this day and age of restrictions on public expenditure, it is not acceptable for the community. Professor Aitkin and other leaders in the academic community are increasingly accessible-and I think the appearance of a series of articles such as this is a good sign-to talk about what happens in universities in the teaching and research programs.

ANSWER.PARA: One thing about which I agree with Professor Aitkin specifically was that public funding of universities cannot, and will not in the next few years, be adequate to meet all of the legitimate needs of research and that it is time that the private sector made a greater contribution to research programs in universities. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures on university research funding show that Australia has the lowest level of many OECD countries of research funding but the highest level of public funding, which points the finger fairly clearly at industry, which has not until recently played an active role in funding university research.

However, I am pleased to report that our Government has made some very successful moves to bring the universities and particularly the research communities, closer to the business communities. As well as that, we have provided for a 150 per cent tax concession for industry funds going into university research. These sorts of measures are starting to bring more private funding into universities. This has a dual benefit. It means that the overall level of funding for the very important research work done in universities is increased, and not just at the expense of the public purse. It also means that university research programs are themselves more responsive and more reactive to the needs of the economy.
Overall, I welcome articles of the kind written by Professor Aitkin. I believe that the general movement towards improved co-operation between business and universities is in the interests of both.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Territories to the occupation of the public area outside Parliament House by demonstrators opposed to Australia's defence alliance with the United States of America, and the action taken by the Department of Territories in April 1985 physically to remove a small group of Vietnamese who were peacefully protesting outside Parliament House. I ask: Why has no similar action been taken against the present demonstrators, who have behaved in a much more intimidatory and violent fashion? How is it that the demonstrators have been able to obtain exclusive use of public amenities such as electricity? Will the Government now act to ensure that these public facilities and this public area are available for the use of all Australians?

—Mr President, yesterday you were asked, as the Presiding Officer of the Senate, to examine the issues raised by Senator Vanstone about the precincts of Parliament House. As I understand it, you have that matter under review. I have no particular advice from the Minister for Territories, but I am sure that he is aware of your inquiries into this matter. However, if there is any way in which the Minister can co-operate with you in this matter, I will certainly draw it to his attention.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security aware that investigations undertaken by the Muscular Dystrophy Association of South Australia have revealed that many disabled people lack information about government benefits, disability services and their own disorder? Is the Minister able to comment on this matter? Will he consider investigating information programs for the disabled to ensure that potential beneficiaries are not missed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not directly aware of the survey to which Senator Elstob referred, but the results of it do not surprise me at all. It is one of the problems of the social security system and the system of government benefits in general in this country that frequently the information about details of those services does not get through to those who need them the most. We have had some glaring examples of this. I remember that we had a subsidised health scheme in 1975-76, information of which did not get to a very high percentage of people. Even the family income supplement, it has been variously estimated, gets to only a very small percentage of those who are eligible.

ANSWER.PARA: The best way to overcome this, I believe, is to do what the Government has been doing, and that is to concentrate assistance for disabled people in self-help groups of the disabled themselves. In doing so, we can ensure that they spread the word to their members about what services and benefits are available. They can assist their members better in applying for those benefits and services and ensuring that they get their full eligibility. They can act as advocates for the groups and give governments a better idea of what services and benefits are appropriate. Certainly, as all governments have done, the Government continues to advertise the availability of services and benefits, but in a country as geographically and demographically diverse as ours this is not the most satisfactory way of distributing such information.

We will continue to work on it. I am certainly disappointed if an organisation such as the Muscular Dystrophy Association has such a finding. One can assume that there is also then some difficulty with the medical profession and other caring professions in distributing the information that they should be playing their part in distributing. However, I will look at the matter. I will refer it to the Minister for Social Security and, I suppose, the Minister for Health to see whether I can get any further information for the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What steps has the Commonwealth Government taken to ensure that the Government of France is aware of Australian concern about environmental degradation due to the construction of an Antarctic air base at Dumont d'Urville? Is it a fact that the Minister received advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs that the Antarctic Division, Hobart, be recommended to refuse assistance requested by the French Government in transporting earth moving equipment to Antarctica aboard a vessel under charter to the Division? If not, what advice did the Minister receive? What reason can the Minister give for the Australian Government's decision to allow French earth moving equipment to be loaded for shipment to Antarctica on board the MS Nella Dan? Finally, can the Minister assure the Senate that Australia maintains its opposition to environmental degradation at Dumont d'Urville?

—Allegations that France has been contravening its obligations under the Antarctic Treaty system in constructing an airstrip at the French Antarctic station Dumont d'Urville have been discussed between French and Australian officials on a number of occasions over the past two years. The French position is that France is not in breach of its obligations and that it is taking steps to monitor closely any work related to the airstrip in order to act to mitigate and minimise its environmental impact. It is not the usual practice to provide details of advice given to Ministers, but in this case the Minister for Foreign Affairs agreed to a request for the use of the Australian chartered Antarctic vessel Nella Dan to transport some plant and equipment from Europe to Hobart by Expeditions Polaires Francaises, EPF. How was that?
—French as a second language.

—I did Latin at school, so honourable senators will have to forgive me. That is the government agency responsible for France's Antarctic program. A French chartered vessel will then take it from Hobart to Dumont d'Urville.
—Oh!
—That is all right, is it not?
—Terrific. Terrific.
—The Government's decision reflects the spirit of co-operation--
—Tres bon.

—Tres chic. The Government's decision reflects the spirit of co-operation which prevails amongst operating agencies of all nations active in Antarctica. In the past the Antarctic Division has given and received logistic support from other nations including its French counterpart. Australia's agreement to assist France on this occasion, therefore, is consistent with past practice and with normal co-operation under the Antarctic Treaty system. The Australian Government's attitude towards the project for construction of an airstrip at the place in question is a separate matter. The Australian Government is continuing to follow closely the environmental effects of the airstrip construction. I should add that it has been reported that French budgetary priorities have affected the pace of the airstrip construction. Our understanding is that a review of the project has recently been requested by the French Government.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women aware of statements made last week by a Liberal member, Mr Downer, in which he described the programs of the Office of the Status of Women as `unscientific' and directed more at `vote winning' than anything else? In particular he referred to the national agenda for women campaign as a `waste of money'. Is there any basis for Mr Downer's comments? Can the Minister indicate to the Senate the range and volume of responses received on the national agenda for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is any basis to the suggestions by Mr Downer except for his suggestion that we may win votes. It is my firm conviction that by taking the women of Australia seriously, by engaging in very detailed consultations with them and by being prepared to tailor policies to reflect what the women of Australia want, we will, in fact, win votes. We have done it before. We did overwhelmingly in 1983 and the Liberal Party of Australia knows that to be the case. We sustained the support of women voters in 1984. I believe at the next election we will again have the confidence of Australian women.

ANSWER.PARA: But the purpose of the Office of the Status of Women is to ensure that all government policies have input, particularly from the women's point of view. The reason why our Government put the Office of the Status of Women in with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet instead of in a smaller outside department was that we were determined that all our policies and legislation would benefit Australian women. Indeed, we have an outstanding record of achieving that objective.

As to the particular criticism that part of the consultation exercise involving the sending in of questionnaires by Australian women is unscientific, let me say this: That part of the exercise was never intended to be a methodologically sophisticated way of determining any particular trend. What it did do was to give Australian women from all walks of life-country women, women in isolated areas, women confined to the home through physical disability, women from non-English speaking backgrounds-the opportunity to make suggestions, recommendations and comments direct to the Government. Hundreds of thousands of those questionnaires have been returned and they are being analysed in a very careful fashion. The views expressed will be added to the views expressed personally to me, to Senator Zakharov and other members of the Government and to members of the National Women's Consultative Council as we engage in this consultation exercise.

I can confidently say that no government has gone to such pains to consult women about their views on any manner of policy areas. The results of all of this consultation will appear in a draft policy document which will be available for further public discussion at the end of the year.

As for Mr Downer's scepticism and disappointment, I think we should remind him of what happened to the Liberal Party's vote among women in 1983 and suggest that, if he is really interested in improving the fortunes of the Liberal Party, perhaps he could take a leaf out of our book and actually listen to women and take note of what they say.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Education to the statement today by the New South Wales Minister for Education, Mr Cavalier, on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's World Today program. It states:

QUESTION.PARA: The hard, inescapable truth is, incredible, that the amount of money spent by the Hawke Government on government school education is less than, in real dollars, than was spent by the Fraser Government when it went out.
Will the Minister confirm the facts as stated by her State colleague?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to confirm these statements because they are not true. I suggest that Senator Teague and Mr Cavalier, my friend and comrade from north of the border who seems to be in a somewhat excited state at the moment, have a close look at the Budget Papers. From memory, I can say that during the seven years of the Fraser Government there was a real negative-a loss in real terms-in the amount of funds going to state schools. Under our general recurrent program for state schools-leaving aside other programs which benefit state schools, such as the disadvantaged schools program-there will be a 50 per cent real increase at the end of the eight-year funding period. For example, this year there will be in the vicinity of a 17 per cent real increase in the per capita general recurrent grants going to state school children. That is just one program I can point to that demonstrates a very different shape in funding.
—What about the total provision?

—I do not know what the honourable senator would like to take into the total provision. For example, would he like to include the Austudy payments which go more substantially to children in government rather than non-government schools? There has been a monumental increase in the money spent for student assistance for children from poorer families. The participation and equity program also provides a global increase to government schools compared to the situation that preceded it. So really Mr Cavalier ought to be a bit calmer and pay a little more attention to Budget documents and a little less attention to some of the self-interested groups that he is dealing with at the moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEATH OF PRESIDENT MACHEL OF MOZAMBIQUE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the tragic death in an air crash of President Machel of Mozambique. What is the Government's reaction to this sad event, and does the Government as yet have any evidence as to who or what may have been responsible for the crash?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government was deeply shocked and saddened to hear of the tragic, as Senator Colston said, and untimely death of President Samora Machel of Mozambique. President Machel was a leading figure in the Frelimo Liberation Movement. He led his country to independence in 1975 and guided its destiny throughout the subsequent period until his death on Sunday evening. President Machel was at the forefront of the frontline state campaign for majority rule in South Africa, as he was some years ago an important supporter of the struggle to end white minority rule in neighbouring Rhodesia. He enjoyed the respect of African, Eastern bloc and Western leaders alike. At home he remained a popular leader commanding widespread support, despite the economic and developmental problems, exacerbated by civil war, which wracked his young country. President Machel was facing a worsening internal security situation in recent times, as the activities of the rebel Renamo guerrillas increased. It is widely accepted that Renamo's activities are encouraged and backed by the South African Government.

ANSWER.PARA: President Machel was returning from Lusaka, where he had been consulting with President Kaunda of Zambia and leaders of the African National Congress over the deteriorating security situation in his country, when his plane crashed on South African territory. We have no evidence to hand as yet as to the cause of that crash, nor is there evidence at this stage that there was any South African involvement in causing the crash. The Australian Government extends its deepest sympathies to the Mozambiquan Government and people and to the families of President Machel and other victims of the crash. It is our Government's sincerest wish that a peaceful succession to the late President's position will be followed by a peaceful solution to Mozambique's problems and that the sudden death of Samora Machel will not serve as an excuse for external interests to exploit the situation in Mozambique to their own advantage. It must be said, finally, that with his death Mozambique has lost a strong and courageous leader and southern Africa a champion of regional peace and security.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. Have police in Canberra been instructed not to intervene in incidents involving the demonstrators who are occupying the lawns opposite Parliament House? If so, by whom? If not, have any charges been laid following yesterday's clashes between the demonstrators, members of the media and members of the Senate?

—One of the fundamental tenets of our democratic society is the right of persons to present themselves and demonstrate to the Parliament about issues with which they are concerned. In the 15 years I have been a senator I have seen groups of young conscripts protesting against Australia's involvement in the war in Vietnam; I have seen disabled persons in their wheelchairs protesting against the social security policies of the Liberal Government; I have seen farmers assembled out the front of Parliament House; and I have seen many other groups which have been concerned with particular interests. Therefore, I do not believe that honourable senators should get too excited about people who have a justifiable concern about the future of our society as it relates to our survival. As I indicated in the answer that I gave to Senator Vanstone, yesterday a question was asked, if my memory is correct, by Senator Crichton-Browne about the current problems outside Parliament House about which you, Mr President, undertook to carry out certain inquiries. I gather that those inquiries are still being examined by you as a Presiding Officer, in concert with the Speaker of the House of Representatives. They are adequately in the hands of responsible persons. Of course, the Minister for Territories may have some particular interest in this, based on past experiences with demonstrations. If there is a necessity for the Minister for Territories to be involved with the Presiding Officers, I am quite happy to draw his attention to the problem.

—Order! I should add my remarks to those that have been made by the Minister representing the Minister for Territories. I point out that yesterday Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question about the alleged lack of access of parliamentarians to Parliament House as a result of a demonstration that took place on the roadway on Sunday. Following that question, I have had an investigation made. I have had discussions with the Speaker and I will respond to Senator Crichton-Browne's question at the end of Question Time.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I direct my question again to Senator Gietzelt and ask: Have the police in Canberra been instructed not to intervene? If so, by whom? If not, have any charges been laid following yesterday's incident?

—I am aware that Senator Knowles is a recent addition to this chamber. If she has any problems associated with the Australian Federal Police, I suggest that we direct that question to the Minister concerned. I am quite happy to do so.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Community Services been drawn to the latest issue of the NSW Nursing Homes Chronicle? In particular, has he seen claims by the Executive Director, a Mr John Gillroy, that the Government does not understand how fees are set and that the Government is to blame for causing worry and uncertainty to elderly people in nursing homes? Would the Minister care to comment on those claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, not surprisingly, my attention has been drawn to the edition of the NSW Nursing Homes Chronicle, which is the journal of the New South Wales private nursing homes. I must say at the outset that I have been contacted by some nursing home proprietors in New South Wales who wish to dissociate themselves from the sort of campaign being conducted by Mr Gillroy and his colleagues. The latest edition of the Chronicle is in fact almost entirely devoted to attacking the Government. In my view it is another example of the way some unscrupulous sections in this group of service providers in the community will indulge in this sort of tactic to attempt to influence the Government's decision-making process. It really makes me wonder whether the eagerness to blame the Government is an attempt to divert the blame away from the nursing home proprietors for the recent fee increases in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: At the instigation of the nursing home proprietors, the Government has approved an increase in the maximum fee that New South Wales nursing homes may charge patients. That is the maximum fee; nobody, let alone the Government, is forcing nursing home proprietors to charge the maximum fee. If Mr Gillroy's members wish to charge less than that fee, they can, and in fact some of them do, but most of them do not. At this time of the year, this Government, as have previous governments since 1977, will also consider an increase in the nursing home benefit. I have made it clear in the Senate that that is what we are doing now. I have made it clear in the Senate that the deliberate untruth perpetrated by Mr Gillroy that we are to freeze nursing home benefits in New South Wales is not true, and has no basis in truth. What happened in New South Wales was that in September the New South Wales Industrial Commission granted nurses a considerable increase and a flow-on of the 38-hour week to nurses in the private sector. Normally the Department, knowing very well how to fix fees in New South Wales, as anywhere else, would consider the costs to nursing homes and increases in costs and increase the fees as a result of investigations of individual cases. In this case we accepted on the basis of the claims of the New South Wales proprietors that they would have, partially, an across the board fee increase. We could not delay granting permission to increase the maximum fee, because this would result later in higher fee increases due to fee loadings.

The Government is considering increasing the nursing home benefit. We will consider that rationally and reasonably and will not be stampeded by the likes of Mr Gillroy. He would make much better use of his organisation's time and resources if he were to redirect them to the task of improving the standards and the quality of life and of care for nursing home patients in New South Wales, all of which have been under criticism from committees of this Senate, independent inquiries outside, and independent organisations of senators. He would do much better to spend his time and his organisation's time in getting those standards improved rather than in pursuing his pre-occupation of where his or some of his colleagues next BMW or Mercedes is coming from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Button, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What other Federal grants have been made by the Hawke Government to Women for Survival, who are presently camped opposite Parliament House, in addition to the $2,000 International Year of Peace grant awarded to them in July for publication purposes? What Government grants have been made to other bodies involved in the Women for Survival protest in addition to the Australian Council grant to Women against Global Violence, who share the same address as the Women's Employment Action Centre in Sydney, a recipient of considerable community employment program funding? Is any Federal funding being provided for the purpose of the demonstration opposite Parliament House, or can any of the existing grants be used for this purpose?
—I have no idea of the answers to any of those questions. I shall endeavour to obtain answers and provide them to Senator Baume as soon as possible.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the document entitled `Social Security Review: Issues Paper No. 1' issued by the Department of Social Security yesterday. Has the Minister noted that the review indicates that since family concepts have been no longer considered by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission specifically since 1974, by comparison with others in the work force the disposable income of workers, whether male or female, with dependent spouses and children has fallen substantially and that these families have been saddled with an unduly greater share of the taxation burden? In discussions on the two-tier wage structure and the new accord, will the Government re-emphasise the importance of the social wage concept involving industrial tribunals and government action and take steps to redress this discrimination against the wage and salary earners at all levels under Federal and State awards?

—I do not know whether it will surprise Senator Harradine to hear that I have not read yesterday's issue of the Social Security Review, but I will do so as soon as possible to try to identify the passage to which he refers. The point of the question, however, is what will be the Government's attitude in discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions about the wages outcome for calendar year 1987, and particularly the so-called two-tier wage system, which has been discussed quite freely in the Press. I will be taking part in discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions on these issues and I will certainly refer to the point which Senator Harradine has raised. It is more of a constructive suggestion than a question, to which I can provide an immediate answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. The Treasurer, Paul Keating, has taken the unusual step of stating publicly that there is a floor under the Australian currency. How much has this support cost the Reserve Bank of Australia since 1 July 1986? Will the Minister acknowledge that putting a floor under the dollar also requires a rise in interest rates and a rundown in reserves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know that the Treasurer had said that. I do not know the context in which he said it and I would like to look at that first. I think that Senator Watson has scrambled a few things. Whether putting a floor under the dollar-if that is the way he wants to put it-costs the Reserve Bank money depends on the final outcome of its currency trading activities and that is not something that can be determined at this stage.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government floated the dollar because under the crawling peg arrangement initiated by the Fraser Government and presided over by Mr Howard for five years, plus the fact that currency markets are open somewhere or other 24 hours a day for at least five days a week, the currency speculators' risks were being effectively underwritten by the Reserve Bank. As Treasurer, Mr Howard presided over that system for five years, but this Government changed it within nine months of coming to office. That has not eliminated currency speculation, of course, but it has eliminated the substantial underwriting of speculators' risks by the Reserve Bank.

Leaving aside the question of how the Reserve Bank's market operations impact on the bank's end of year profit, I think Senator Watson also suggested that Reserve Bank intervention forced up interest rates. To the degree that it is necessary to maintain some equilibrium in monetary movements, at least in the short term, if the Reserve Bank, or any central bank, maintained a particular value for a currency, that would have the opposite effect for the same outcome. In other words, if the Reserve Bank, or any central bank, were not operating in that way in order to maintain equilibrium in monetary payments, interest rates would be higher than they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an article in Sunday's Sun Herald in which the Deputy Leader of the National Party is reported as saying that primary producers would be forced to borrow money to comply with the fringe benefits tax? Can the Minister provide any information which would indicate whether Mr Hunt's statement is accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one would expect, Mr Hunt's statement is wrong. The Commissioner of Taxation stated last week that 85 per cent of primary producers would have no fringe benefits tax liability.
—Rubbish!

—I repeat that 85 per cent of primary producers will have no fringe benefits tax liability. Of course taxation experts on the other side of the Senate would dispute that, but that is what the Taxation Commissioner says and he is the person who is in the best position to know and he has no political axe to grind. Eighty-five per cent of farmers are exempt.

ANSWER.PARA: I trust that Mr Hunt was not collaborating with the Queensland Government which recently announced that a $50,000 loan at 4 per cent interest would be made available to help farmers pay their fringe benefits tax liability. Presumably, that is just another way of opening up another window for National Party cronies to receive 4 per cent loans financed by the taxpayers. The condition for eligibility is not likely to be a liability to pay fringe benefits tax, but a solid record as a toady and a crony of the National Party Government.

It is a little surprising, however, that Mr Hunt would go out of his way, apparently, to support the Bjelke-Petersen Government in that way when the Queensland National Party Government has consistently dumped on the Federal coalition on this question. It is only a few months since the National Party in Queensland was running advertisements which stated that only the Queensland National Party was totally opposed to the fringe benefits tax, thereby dumping not only on the Federal Liberal Party but also on the Federal National Party, because at that time Mr Hunt was saying that a coalition government would tax fringe benefits such as houses, interest free loans, expensive cars and free education. Since then Mr Hunt has temporarily bitten his tongue because of the babble of discordant voices that was coming out of members of the Opposition and the partially successful attempt by the Leader of the Opposition to gag them.

Finally, it is absolutely untrue that farmers as a group will be affected by the fringe benefits tax. A small minority will incur a fringe benefits tax liability. Those who purport to speak in the name of farmers ought to be supporting the fringe benefits tax, not opposing it, because if the money is not raised by the fringe benefits tax it will have to be raised in some other way. A likely way to raise it, which is probably what the Opposition has in mind if it ever comes to government, is to cancel the 100 per cent rebate on distillate used on farms, because when the Liberal-Country Party coalition was in government it refused to pay that rebate. This Government has done it. If that rebate were to be cancelled, as no doubt the Opposition intends to do, that would recover about $140m of the $600m which the fringe benefits tax will raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister not concerned at the counter-productive effect on Australia's image in Asia and the Pacific due to the hardship being caused by the relatively small economies effected by charging university fees to overseas students? Would the Minister agree that, while there is every reason to expect students from affluent overseas families to pay fees, there is a foreign relations value to Australia in a system which would exempt or subsidise fees in deserving cases? I refer especially to students who are being forced to discontinue their education here when they are close to completing their qualifications. Will the Government give active consideration to such a means tested scholarship system?

—I will need to refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs for a more substantial reply than I am able to give at the moment. Might I just say that it is the case, even with some of the new measures that have been introduced for reasons of budgetary stringency, that we are to spend something like $88m next year in free subsidisation for overseas students. It is also the case that students coming here from Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific areas do not pay any fees at all. We are indeed conscious of the foreign relations implications of matters of this kind. I know that there are concerns in some quarters, particularly about some fee categories for post-graduate students and so on. I am conscious that the Government is conscious of that. It is just something that has been forced upon us by budgetary considerations, not something to which we are insensitive so far as the implications are concerned.

—Is the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware of recent reports which reveal an inclination in the media to depict Vietnam veterans as unstable individuals who habitually commit serious crimes? What action can the Government take to ensure that the good name of Australian Vietnam veterans as a group is not unfairly damaged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a tendency on the part of the media in court cases relating to persons who are Vietnam veterans to use rather extravagant terms drawing on the person's alleged experience in Vietnam as the reason for the action which has caused the case to come before the court. I have no wish, of course, to become involved in a debate about whether the experience in Vietnam is a factor in a particular case because that is a matter for the court to determine. However, some recent media reports that have come to my attention irresponsibly suggest that Vietnam veterans, as a group, are prone to act lawlessly without regard to the safety of others. I am concerned because a number of Vietnam veterans have drawn my attention to this.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government takes the view, I think correctly, that the great majority of Vietnam veterans are law-abiding citizens and lead their lives selflessly, in the same way as any other citizen in this country. In fact a prison census that was carried out in Victoria in 1983 shows that the number of Vietnam veterans in Victorian prisons is only one-third of the number that would have been expected if Vietnam veterans had the same imprisonment rates as all Victorian males of comparable age. The evidence relates to the number of people serving prison sentences. There has been a tendency, therefore, to concentrate on the violent nature of crimes allegedly committed by Vietnam veterans. Two particular cases have been specifically drawn to my attention. In the two cases I am referring to, neither of the persons concerned was a Vietnam veteran.

I intend, as a result of the matter that has been drawn to my attention by Senator Childs, to take this matter up with the Attorney- General to find out what action might be available to the Government to discourage misinformation of this kind. I believe that this is important because spurious claims in Australian courts concerning the status of Vietnam veterans and the irresponsible reporting that flows from that can be detrimental to the good name and peace of mind of those who served in Vietnam. To that extent, the Government deprecates the irresponsibility that flows from some of the exaggerated claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the women's camp on the lawns opposite Parliament House? Has the Government received reports, or is it aware of and will it act on any reports on the camp, from Senator Reynolds, Senator Giles or Senator Tate? Which senator's report has been accepted by the Government as a true reflection of the behaviour in the camp? Is the Government intending to honour the Prime Minister's promise made yesterday that the Government will not tolerate the continued exclusion of the public from the front lawns of Parliament House? If so, when? In view of the fact that a men's camp has now been established on the lawns, will the Minister confirm that the men will receive equally favoured treatment from the Government?

—I hope that the men will receive equal treatment to the women. After all, we are all into that in this decade and I think it would be appropriate if they received the same treatment. I know of no complaints from Senator Reynolds, Senator Giles or Senator Tate. They have not been brought to my attention. Finally, going up the honourable senator's list of questions rather than down, I am aware that women are camped on the lawns.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I simply draw the Minister's attention to the fact that a part of the question is unanswered. Is the Government intending to honour the Prime Minister's promise made yesterday that the Government will not tolerate the continued exclusion of the public from the front lawns of Parliament House? If so, when?
—That is not a matter directly for the Government. I assume the Prime Minister to be saying that, if there is any breach of law, that will be attended to. That is all I am assuming.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health been drawn to a statement by Mr Ashley Goldsworthy, the Chief Executive of the Suncorp Building Society in Brisbane, relating to the Australia Card? Further, Mr Goldsworthy claimed that the Health Insurance Commission would be able to delve into records of the Taxation Office, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Australian Electoral Commission. Can the Minister outline the details of the Australia Card in light of the claims made by Mr Goldsworthy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did note the statement by Mr Goldsworthy and I noted that Mr Goldsworthy was the Chief Executive of the Suncorp Building Society in Queensland. I was very concerned about that. His statement was so full of inaccuracies and demonstrated such extraordinary ignorance that I would be very concerned if I were an investor with the Suncorp Building Society. However, I soon got an explanation as to why Mr Goldsworthy made these ridiculous statements when I found that in fact he is the Federal Vice-President of the Liberal Party of Australia. I dare say that it was in that capacity that he made the particularly stupid statements he has made, and not in his capacity as the Chief Executive of the Suncorp Building Society, although if he has such difficulty in determining which hat he wears-the shady one as Federal Vice-President of the Liberal Party or the other as Chief Executive of the Suncorp Building Society-I would be concerned about having my money in his organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Goldsworthy is obviously trying to distract attention from the fact that when the Liberal and National parties were in government they did nothing much-I was about to say something rude then-about tax evasion and welfare fraud. The Liberal Party's opposition to the Australia Card-and I assume it is as Vice-President of the Liberal Party--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your intimidation--
—Will someone give that senator a saucer of milk?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The attack which has been made by the Minister on Mr Goldsworthy is not in breach of the Standing Orders and nor is his besmirching of the commercial reputation of an organisation which happens to have engaged in it someone who dares to be a member of the Liberal Party. That sort of pathetic behaviour is not in breach of the Standing Orders. However, his comments to Senator Walters are, I think, in breach. He should be made to withdraw and apologise.

—Order! As to the point which related to the way in which Senator Grimes was answering the question asked by Senator Jones, the Minister is clearly in order. As far as his comments about a senator who interjected are concerned, I suggest that his remarks were uncalled for and I ask for a withdrawal.

—Of course, Mr President. Perhaps we will have no more interjections. As for Senator Chaney's remarks, I am not taking up the point of order but I point out that he implied that my remarks about Mr Goldsworthy's remarks were uncalled for. Mr Goldsworthy said:

ANSWER.PARA: No other Western democratic nation operates such comprehensive surveillance of its citizens-as would be operated under the Australia Card.

There are identification systems in France, Italy, Sweden, Denmark, Belgium, Switzerland, West Germany, Israel and Hong Kong, and de facto identification systems in the United States of America and Canada, all of which are and can be used for more purposes than those for which the Australia Card will be used. In many of these countries it is compulsory for people to produce their identification card on demand, whereas in Australia there will be no need to carry the card and it will need to be produced only for certain functions which are specified in the legislation. Therefore, Mr Goldsworthy's statement is untrue, and that statement, made by him as the senior executive of an organisation which may be caring for Senator Chaney's money or my money must be considered to be coming from him as the Vice-President of the Liberal Party. If he was speaking as the Vice-President of the Liberal Party, that is fine, but he put out his statement and his Press statement as the Chief Executive of the Suncorp Building Society. If he wants to be judged on his political statements, I say that if he was speaking as Vice-President of the Liberal Party I would not be answering the question; but he has claimed to be speaking as the Chief Executive of the Suncorp Building Society. If he cannot get his facts right there, what is he doing with the money of the people of Queensland?

There will be no central data bank of information in Australia, as claimed by Mr Goldsworthy. All that will be on the Australia Card register is basic identification information-name, address, date of birth, sex and details of the documentation used to verify the identity. To establish the Australia Card register, the Health Insurance Commission will have access to the records of seven government agencies. This access is strictly limited to the initial establishment of the register, except in the case of records held by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. So again Mr Goldsworthy was quite wrong in the statements he made in that regard. I would ask Mr Goldsworthy what personal information he and his organisation, the Suncorp Building Society, have on their computer files. As it happens, we know. We will be interested to see whether he is willing to let people know. The personal information on the files of the Suncorp Building Society is much more extensive than anything that will be contained on the Australia Card register. Most people do not have any idea of what information on them is kept by the organisation that is run by Mr Goldsworthy and they do not have the opportunity to correct that information, as they will with the Australia Card. I have no problems with Mr Goldsworthy opposing the Australia Card's introduction. I have no problems with his speaking as a Vice-President of the Liberal Party. I do have a problem with his speaking as the Executive Director of the Suncorp Building Society and not indicating to the people of Australia his party political role. If he wants to do that, he has to cop criticism in this place, as any of us can and do cop criticism without too much complaint, with the exception of Senator Walters, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education: Is it a fact that the Dora Turner School-the school that does a wonderful job educating many intellectually disabled children-has had its funding cut by 8.5 per cent for 1986 and has been informed that it will also have a cut of approximately 10 per cent for 1987? Can the Minister tell the Senate how she expects the appropriate level of education to be continued, particularly to these sorts of children, with an 18.5 per cent reduction in their funds?

—Mr President, I do not have at hand in the Senate information on particular schools. If Senator Walters would like to send details of that particular school to my office, I will have the matter investigated.

—My question, which is about Queensland, is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen the results of the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics survey of private enterprise investment spending in the various States of Australia? Do these results indicate that the Australian business community regards Queensland as a particularly good State in which to invest?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that question is no, but I think I should give a bit more detail.
—Provided that the honourable senator does not debate the question.

—Certainly. Heaven forbid, Mr President. The ABS catalogue No. 5646.0, released on 17 October, refers to both actual private business investment to March of this year and the expected investment during the 1986-87 financial year as a whole. It shows that between the December quarter 1985 and the March quarter 1986 private business investment in Queensland fell by almost 27 per cent in current prices-slightly more than that in real prices-which was, of course, the worst result of any State. That can be attributed, however, partially to seasonal factors. It might be more reliable to look at the figures for the March quarter 1986 compared with the same quarter of the previous year. That shows that, in this whole-year period, private business investment in Queensland did increase by almost 10 per cent, again in current or nominal prices, but the national figure for that same period was 20 per cent. In other words, the rate of increase of private business investment in Queensland was 10 per cent lower than it was in Australia as a whole. The same sort of picture emerges if we look at the expectations of business investment during 1986-87, as compared with actual investment spending during the 12 months to March 1986. In Queensland the anticipated investment for the 12 months ended June 1987 will be more than 22 per cent less than actual investment in the year to March 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: Some members of the Opposition have attempted to make a major issue of the fact that the Budget Papers forecast a very slight real decline in business investment spending in this financial year in all of Australia, but in Queensland the anticipated decline in monetary terms is more than 22 per cent. Just by the way, the second worse State so far as private business investment is concerned is Tasmania.

But the business expectations data clearly indicate that the policies of the present Queensland State Government are not conducive to healthy private investment. That is not surprising because people-other than those who are part of the National Party crony circuit, which prevails in Queensland-do not have any interest in investing in a State like that, governed under the present Administration. Perhaps in a month or two that opinion may be changed. The prospect of private business investment in Queensland would improve appreciably if the present State Government were to be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time in reply to Senator Giles, I informed the Senate that the Queensland and Tasmanian governments had attended a high level conference on legislative and award restrictions to women's employment. I regret to inform the Senate that this was not the case and that all State governments were represented, excluding Queensland and Tasmania. I also said that the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry had issued a joint communique agreeing to resolve all issues by the end of 1988 and that the communique was supported by South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales. In fact, the communique was supported by South Australia, Victoria and the Northern Territory.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY MOTOR VEHICLE REGISTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Reid asked me a question about the Australian Capital Territory Motor Vehicle Registry. I promised an early response. The Minister for Territories has provided the following answer: The question raised by Senator Reid relates to criticism of procedures by a judge of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court which was reported in the Canberra Times of 17 October 1986. The judge's comments relate to matters arising in 1984 in a case allegedly involving stolen vehicles. The matter raised has been examined and action is being taken. Since 1983 procedures have been in place to check the status of private vehicles presented for original registration. If ownership papers are not available a check is made by phone to the Australian Federal Police. Procedures relating to vehicles presented by licensed vehicle dealers are being reviewed and all States and Territories are examining how to achieve a nation-wide register of stolen vehicles which should overcome these problems.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time yesterday Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question relating to police action in closing a road near Parliament House during a demonstration on Sunday, 19 October. I have now received a report from the Australian Federal Police confirming that on a number of occasions on Sunday police diverted traffic away from a section of King George Terrace in front of Parliament House. I am told that that action was taken by them to ensure the safety of a large number of demonstrators, estimated by them to be about 500, who were performing dance routines on the road and obstructing the flow of traffic. I am advised, however, that at no stage were vehicles prevented from having access to Parliament House. I believe the action taken by the police was appropriate in the circumstances.

INTERJECT.PARA: In that context, an item on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio news this morning stated that the President of the Senate was investigating incidents which allegedly occurred yesterday at the demonstrators' camp on the lawns in front of Parliament House. I should make it clear and I emphasise that my responsibilities as President of the Senate, together with those of my colleague the Speaker of the House of Representatives, are confined to the parliamentary precincts and the rights of senators and members to unhindered access to Parliament House. My investigations have been confined solely to the matter raised by Senator Crichton-Browne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move that the Senate take note of the statement.
—Do you intend this to be a long debate-like all afternoon?
—No, I do not intend it to be a long debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

In response to the Manager of Government Business (Senator Grimes), who asked whether I proposed a long debate, I say that that is not my intention. I simply thought it would be an appropriate time to make a brief comment on the matters which have been raised in your statement, Mr President. Your statement relates to a specific question asked by Senator Crichton-Browne yesterday in the context of a number of actions being taken in the Senate including the giving of notices of motion by three Liberal senators relating to incidents which had occurred outside Parliament House. Those matters have had extensive coverage in the media. There has been a great deal of interest in them, I suppose not the least because representatives of the media themselves have been subjected to some ill-treatment, including physical ill-treatment, which has naturally excited their interest.

But, Mr President, my purpose in speaking now is simply to make quite clear the concerns of the Opposition and to make it quite clear that it is not the position of the Opposition to in any way object to the people of Australia coming to Canberra and making their views known to the politicians who work in this building. We accept that over the years many different groups have done that. We have recently had very large gatherings of farmers and I think this morning we had a very large gathering of school teachers who have been here protesting about the Government's education policies. We have had people objecting to the administration of immigration laws, and on it goes. It is no part of the Opposition's stance on this matter to seek in any way to criticise or limit the civil liberties of Australians to make their protest where they believe that the Government, or indeed the Opposition, is taking stances with which they disagree. The sole concerns expressed by the Opposition related to behaviour which in the view of the Opposition infringes the civil liberties not only of members of this Parliament but of other Australian citizens who are seeking in turn to go about their lawful business. They may wish to protest on an entirely different matter. The concerns that have been expressed in the notices of motion given and the questions put in this chamber today to different Government Ministers and yesterday to you, Mr President, all relate to what are seen as attempts by people involved in this particular demonstration to trample upon the rights and liberties of others. There have been concerns about their exclusive occupation of ground and about their physical behaviour towards some senators and members of the public, and we make no apology for expressing in the clearest possible terms our objection to that and our belief that it is the duty of the Government, by means of its control of the administration of the Australian Capital Territory, to protect the rights of all Australians against interference from this or indeed any other group.

I do not believe it is appropriate to discuss at great length the matters which concern honourable senators. They are expressed in the notices given by those senators yesterday and in the questions raised. But it is totally unacceptable to members of the Opposition that their right to passage across the Parliamentary Triangle should be impeded, that they should be subjected not to argument but to abuse and that there should be spitting and physical assault. Those matters are beyond the bounds of what is reasonable. They are outside the democratic tradition that we as an Opposition are committed to supporting totally and we believe that the onus is on the Government to ensure that, if people abuse the privileges which are made available to them in having access to the Parliament in that way, those abuses cease and if there are breaches of the law they should be appropriately dealt with.

I hope there will be no attempt to confuse in people's minds the Opposition's stance on these matters. We are totally committed to the pursuit of peace. It would appear that our means of pursuing peace differ from those which are advocated by the women who have congregated opposite. We express their right to have a different view but we believe that in many of the views they are putting forward they are playing into the hands of those who in fact would not cause peace but would cause war. That is a very significant difference between them and us. We expect that as part of the democratic process, but I on behalf of the Opposition express our total commitment to the pursuit of peace through the policies that we have often spoken about in this chamber. In the same way I express the absolute support of the Opposition for the right of assembly and the right of protest. We say that in Australia those rights can be exercised within the law and without trespassing on the rights of others. The Corporation's stocks amounted to 168.1 mkg at the start of the year and at the end of the year were 159.1 mkg. That is a reasonably encouraging position. It is more important now than ever that the Australian community realises the risk to the wool industry's contribution to the national economy of any relaxation in the promotion effort. There are no inherent loyalties to wool in the highly competitive international textile fibre markets. Synthetic fibres are developing more technical sophistication and consumer appeal, and have become the subject of integrated promotion campaigns similar to those that have served wool so well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wool, comprising one of the nation's largest industries, accounts for some 10 per cent of exports and in 1985-86 earned more than $3,100m. It is responsible for the administration of a reserve price scheme, for servicing the wool marketing system, and for administering wool stores. It also promotes wool textile products and provides direction for research and industry development. The Corporation's annual report highlights the importance of the wool industry to Australia. While most market indicators have been depressed, I would emphasise that the wool industry has provided a degree of stability to the economy. The world demand for wool textiles increased by 3 per cent in 1985, and Australia's sheep flock continued to rise in order to meet this demand. I agree with Senator Brownhill that the industry could face problems if sheep numbers were to rise too dramatically.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite these results I am concerned about the Government's lack of encouragement for downstream industries. It is not encouraging sufficiently new industries that could provide additional employment by using our natural resources. Wool, as part of our industries, has traditionally been Australia's export life-blood. However we can no longer rely on wool and on the meat and wheat industries, et cetera et cetera, as well as the mining industry to maintain our current high standard of living. The present over-supply of many primary products on world markets and the depressed commodities prices are a clear signal that Australia should be developing its secondary industries. Only by strengthening our manufacturing base can we hope to improve our standard of living. I hope that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will take this into account when he looks at the contribution of the wool textile industry in the textiles, clothing and footwear debate and the Government's support for that industry. Australia is richly endowed with natural resources and we are technologically advanced. If we can develop our secondary industries by starting with downstream manufacturing, using our natural resources. This would be preferable to only exporting the raw produce overseas.

In 1985-86 the Australian wool industry again faced the challenge from increasing overseas competition and from an unfavourable domestic and overseas economic environment. Australian growers have not only had to cope with international pressures but also with pressures created by our domestic climate. High interest rates over the past year have badly affected our markets and our producers' viability. I wish to express my concern and disappointment that an extraordinarily large proportion of the carpeting for the New Parliament House will be New Zealand produced carpet. The new House will be a unique feature and it is at odds that Australian wool, one of our traditional products, will be so underrepresented in this fine building.

I also warn the Government of the damage that could be done by allowing our unique breeds of merino rams to be exported overseas. The country that is most likely to take advantage of this to our detriment is China, which is the third largest wool producer. It has a rapidly expanding sheep industry and it could prove a threat to Australia's traditional markets in the near future, especially if it is given the opportunity to develop its fine sheep breeding program at a cost to the Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This paper was not available prior to its being tabled, so I have not had a chance to examine it as closely as I would have wished.
