It records also:
Since the commencement of the Plan there has been a steady improvement in labour productivity, capital investment and output.

In the case of the steel industry, there will be broad acceptance that the fining down of the work force, difficult as that has been for some individuals, has been very necessary and the increase in productivity which has followed both improved labour practices and increased capital investment is typical of the changes and improvements which are necessary across a much wider range of Australian industry. I wish, on behalf of the Opposition, to express pleasure and satisfaction at the progress which has been made and to express the hope that that progress will continue.

The report, however, does not contain only good news. I wish to touch on a matter which was raised in the Estimates committee with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, and which came up again in Question Time only yesterday when Senator Button responded to a question from Senator McIntosh, namely, the worrying resurgence of industrial difficulties in the steel industry and the apparent resistance which is emerging to further improvements, not least in the work practices area. I want to raise that matter now because it seems to me from the answer which the Minister gave yesterday to Senator McIntosh and the answers he gave in the Estimates committee that he is affecting a certain lack of concern about what I think are some very worrying trends in what has emerged. Yesterday, in response to an interjection I made while the Minister was replying to Senator McIntosh's question, the Minister suggested that there was just a slight hiccup in 1986 which has taken us back to a performance which is one-seventh of the man hours lost under the coalition Government. I suggest to the Minister that that is a very exaggerated view of how good things are at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I agree with that. It is about one-half.

—The Minister now suggests that it is about one-half. I draw his attention to the figures contained at page 19 of the report, where the passage in industrial disputes starts. It is made quite clear in the tables which follow that there has been a very significant lift in the number of man hours lost. Whilst it may give proper satisfaction to the Minister to say that it is still better than it has been in some historic period, he can get very little satisfaction from a situation where at Port Kembla in the half year to June 1986 there was a 684 per cent increase in the amount of industrial disputation, a 46 per cent increase at Newcastle and only an 11 per cent increase at Whyalla, but that was after a half year to December 1985 where there had been a 397 per cent increase. Overall, in the first half of 1986 there has been an increase of 266 per cent in the number of man hours lost through industrial disputes in the steel division of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd as a whole. That is described by the Steel Industry Authority as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an alarming increase in man hours lost through industrial disputes leading to a loss of production and wages in the second half of 1985-86, particularly at Port Kembla where man hours lost through industrial disputes increased by over 680 per cent in the second half of the year.

My time has almost expired, but I simply wish to say that there needs to be acceptance at both the management and labour levels that the sorts of improvements which have occurred are not improvements which will solve the problems for all time. There is clearly a need for the increases in productivity to be continued. In this as in other industries Australia is pursuing moving targets-other countries will not stand still. The relative success which has been achieved by the steel industry over the last few years, success which we warmly welcome, is something that must not be frittered away by a return to the very bad old habits of the past.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill puts into effect a large number of Budget measures in the areas of social security and veterans' affairs. The provisions are mean and it is a miserable Budget in the areas of social security and veterans' affairs. It has been seen as mean and miserable in the community. I have in front of me a document entitled `Community Responses to the 1986-87 Budget' produced by the Australian Council of Social Service and two of the State councils of social service. I quote just some of the headlines in the document, which was circulated within the welfare community, which read: `Slashed deficit means unemployment growth'. This is a Budget about unemployment growth. Other headings read `No strategy for structural problems'; `No relief for poorest'; `Deferrals and broken promises'-these are the headings on each of the articles-and `Labour market programs abandoned'. Under housing is the heading `Still waiting . . . '-still waiting for housing. Under children is the heading `Women and children under attack'; and under pensioners `Learning to live on less'. Under ethnic communities is the heading `Multiculturalism betrayed'; under women `No equity for women'; and under young people `Priority what?'. This document was produced not by a conservative group in society but by the Australian Council of Social Service, the peak organisation, speaking on behalf of welfare organisations throughout Australia and it has concluded that the Budget is mean, miserable and ill-directed in the areas of social security and veterans' affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Because this Bill represents part of the package of Budget measures, the Opposition will not oppose the legislation. However, we do not like or approve all the components of the legislation. It is with reluctance that we will not oppose some of the matters that are in it for they impact unreasonably upon the poor, the weak and the needy in ways which actually are a betrayal of any Labor government. It is our decision that we will not oppose the legislation, however reluctantly we came to that decision. It is our belief that this wretched, uncaring, clumsy government is still entitled to Supply and to the passage of its Appropriation Bills.

The main components of this Bill, first in the social security area, involve a deferral of the pension rises which pensioners could have expected reasonably in the first pay after November. The Bill provides for a deferral of new asset threshold limits and it provides for a deferral of new levels and limits for fringe benefits determinations. These have all been deferred for six weeks. The Government is proud to announce that this will involve savings of $129m in a full year. But these are savings which the Government is making out of the hides of pensioners in the Australian community. If that is the Government's priority we would like to hear it explain and tell us why it is.

The Bill provides further that certain family allowances are to be means tested. We are told that this will save $49m in a full year out of the hides of families. The Bill puts into effect benefit withdrawals from pensioners and families. The Bill also provides that certain measures to reduce some poverty traps are to be deferred for eight months. This will save $147m out of the hides of those who are caught by poverty traps. The Bill actually provides also-I should acknowledge this for the Government-some new and increased benefits. For double orphans with wooden legs and groups such as that it will mean a total number of extra benefits of $34.5m in a full year. Honourable senators should note the very small amount of extra benefits compared to the very large amount of benefit withdrawals. The Bill provides that there will be new thresholds to allow people to qualify for rental assistance. That will save $10.3m in a full year at the cost of needy renters in society.

It is not a very inspiring social security package for the Hawke Labor Government to bring to the people. In the area of veterans' provisions there is not much more joy. The legislation provides that war widows and one category of service pensioners will lose their access to the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme, although they will still have access to the same pharmaceutical benefits to which we all have access. That will provide some savings out of the hides of war widows and some service pensioners. War widows who also receive an age pension will have the social security component frozen at $60.05 per week. But the other Budget decision, which was announced on Budget night, to provide a reducing permanent maximum level for those people has been dropped in the face of community pressure. Nevertheless, the savings that will be made in this area will be made at the expense of war widows. This is scarcely a great piece of legislation because we can show each vulnerable group who is paying for the decisions.

Provision is made under this legislation to implement the Budget decision to seek to claim certain hospital costs from private health insurance funds where veterans happen to carry private health insurance cover. It is being provided administratively that a veteran will have to sign a clearance to allow the Health Insurance Commission to proceed with requesting payment for treatment from the private health insurance funds. Under the veterans' entitlements in the Bill there is provision for deferral of the consumer price index veterans-related pension increase for three pay days-again, savings to be made out of the hides of veterans and ex-servicemen, most of whom risked their lives so that governments, such as this one, could operate in a democratic society.

Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Bill also provides some minor amendments to clarify existing intentions and the removal of any doubt over the eligibility for benefits of certain members of philanthropic organisations, such as the Red Cross and the Salvation Army. The Bill also provides for benefits in certain deceased estate situations.

That is what the Bill is about. It is mean legislation. It is mean legislation directed at the most needy, the weakest and the most vulnerable in Australian society. Its purpose is to try to help to manage the economic mess in which Australia has been placed by the incompetence of the Hawke Government. But it is designed to seek assistance in managing that economic mess by requiring the most needy, the most vulnerable, the poorest and the most dependent in society to lose, to have limited, or to have deferred the benefits and the cash they need to keep them out of poverty. Poverty is what it is all about. My colleague Senator Richard Alston produced a working paper for us on the question of the unemployment benefit. He made some comments in that paper about poverty, and I intend to quote them. He says:
In Australia there are more than 2 million people below the poverty line-and the social welfare bill has doubled over the last 5 years to $21 billion.
He goes on to say:
. . . still there are 627,000 registered unemployed.
This is in spite of all the efforts we have put into social welfare. He points out:
But what is most disturbing is that whereas in 1983-the worst year for unemployment under the previous Coalition government-the average period of unemployment was 34.3 weeks, now it is 51.9 weeks.
That was the average period of unemployment in one year. Poverty in Australia is what it is about.

I wish to say something further on the question of poverty. We know that poverty is increasing under Labor as a result of economic mismanagement and because it has no social security policy which will help Australians in poverty and in need. It has led the Government to direct some of its economic restraint to these people by bringing this Bill before us today. At present, one in five children in Australia are growing up in poverty. The 1986 Budget offered not a glimmer of hope that those Australians living on benefits and pensions, living in poverty or on the edge of poverty, could look forward to a better life. There were no structural changes designed to come to grips with the major problems or with outdated practices.

I am not alone in deciding that the Budget is deficient as a social instrument and that it contains no body of theory or purpose that would offer those in greatest need any hope. I need look no further than the chairman of the Australian Labor Party's own Caucus committee on welfare, Senator John Coates, who made his views perfectly clear. I refer honourable senators to a recent article in the Australian headed `Budget condemned by leading ALP man'. According to the Australian, that leading ALP man was Senator John Coates. He is the chairman of the Labor Party's caucus welfare committee. Senator Coates is reported as having said-I believe that the report is accurate and that he said this-that the poor will fall further into poverty under the Keating 1986-87 Budget. This is not what I am saying; this is what Senator John Coates of the Labor Party is saying. He is saying that the poor will fall further into poverty as a result of the 1986-87 Keating Budget. The second thing which Senator John Coates said, and which was reported in the Australian newspaper, was that the burden of the Budget, the economic burden in Australia, was not being shared equally, let alone equitably, as promised; instead, the greatest burden is falling upon the poor.

This Bill seeks to implement some of the changes which led Senator John Coates to make those comments about the Budget. Not only this, but there has been inequality in the calls for sacrifice in Australia in the past year. There have been some crazy sets of priorities. How can a government which asks the Parliament to put off benefits for pensioners and the relief of poverty traps-to take all the measures identified in this legislation-tell us of the money it is to put into the defence of the America's Cup? That may be a very worthy thing to see, and I hope that Australia can retain that yachting trophy. But how can it have a priority for calls upon the public purse while the Government decides to defer for another eight months measures to relieve poverty traps?

Last year we had the spectacle of the Government giving relief for racehorse purchase. The three measures it introduced last year for that relief came into effect immediately. Last year in the Budget the Government promised these same measures to relieve poverty traps, but while it gave immediate relief for racehorse purchase it said that people would have to wait until October 1986 for poverty traps relief. It is now telling us that people have to wait yet another eight months. Does the Government not have some sense of priorities, some sense of social justice, some sense of equal sharing? This Government cannot claim that it is sharing the load equitably. I am pleased that I can look forward to some promised tax cuts, but I feel uneasy that I am getting my tax cuts and that those who want relief from their poverty traps have to wait another eight months. That indicates the Government's set of priorities. The burden is not being shared equally.

I return to a couple of the main measures in this legislation. I want to discuss firstly the proposals to defer the granting to pensioners of, first, their pension rises; secondly, their new assets test threshold, which of course would ease the application of the assets test for many of them; and, thirdly, their new income limits for other benefits, which again would ease the burden upon some of them. This will mean for that class of Australians-a very large and dependent class-less cash in hand, less cash than they were promised by this Government when it was seeking a mandate at the polls, and a lesser ability to qualify for benefits, to satisfy the assets and income tests for various benefits. Australian pensioners do not enjoy a comfortable or an affluent standard of living. It is a careful and austere living standard that is provided by our social security system. It is true that if the nation faces an economic crisis, we should all share in the battle for Australia's economic survival; but we should share with some kind of equality. It seems a bit sick that these deferrals are to apply to pensioners while those of us who are lucky enough to have jobs can look forward to receiving our tax cuts immediately.

There are also other kinds of inequality. I mention in passing, that while the pensioners are asked to do without, some very substantial pay rises in the public sector have been granted in the past year. In the past year, the head of the Department which has been responsible for preparing this legislation-the permanent head of the Department of Social Security or the Department of Veterans' Affairs-has had a pay increase, as a result of Remuneration Tribunal determinations, from over $81,000 to over $84,000. While we are telling the pensioners that they have to wait and do without, while we are telling people that they cannot have relief from their poverty traps, that permanent head has taken an extra $3,000 and the heads of the top Public Service departments in the same year have had their salaries increased from over $88,000 to almost $92,000. Oh yes; we will talk about equality of sacrifice, will we not? We politicians have actually voted away a large part of our increase. We did this in the Parliament a couple of weeks ago; but some very large pay increases have been awarded to statutory officers and those covered by the Remuneration Tribunal at the same time as this mean, deprivatory legislation seeks to put the burden upon those who are weakest and least able to care for themselves. In relation to the assets test limits, I say very simply that we will abolish Labor's assets test lock, stock and barrel. That is on the public record and it is well known.

The other issue that I wish to discuss concerns the question of poverty trap elimination and the Government's expression of priorities. These are Labor's priorities: At a time of economic crisis, one way to save money is to make those caught by poverty traps, after having made them wait from the time of the Budget in 1985 to October 1986, wait yet another eight months before they can get the relief promised by the poverty trap measure. That says something about Labor's set of priorities. It says something about its preparedness to let the weakest suffer now and suffer most. Letting people continue to suffer the cruelty of poverty traps makes it not worth while for them to try to work their way out of dependence to independence. That measure is to be put off for another eight months. It explains just how much this Government has lost its way. Not only has it lost its way in public opinion but also it has lost its sense of social priorities and its purposes. It has lost any sense of what a Labor government traditionally has been about.

In the parliamentary debate in December 1985 on the Social Security (Poverty Traps Reduction) Bill 1985 I made the point, and I make it again, that poverty traps can operate to have people paying more than $1 by way of lost benefit and tax together on every extra dollar's income they earn. I gave examples in that debate of people who are being taxed at the rate of $1.29 in the dollar. For every dollar they earned, they lost $1.29. One of the poverty trap measures is in fact a poverty trap reduction. The other two, although they will not eliminate the poverty trap, would have helped people who want to do nothing more than to help themselves.

I want to know why the Government has decided that one of its priorities in this Budget is to make people wait another eight months, until 1 July 1987, before the poverty trap reduction measures come into effect. What social good does Labor think it is achieving? What greater purpose is being pursued by making people suffer when all they want to do is help themselves? The Australian Labor Party's priorities are disgusting. As I said before, this legislation is mean and disgusting. It confirms what we know about this Government. It is a government of fixers for powerful interests. That is what it has become; that is what it does. It looks after the powerful; it looks after its mates; it looks after its cronies. But, as for the weakest, the poorest and the most vulnerable, it is too bad for them. This Government has harmed the most vulnerable. No wonder then that Senator Coates and Mr Gerry Hand-both from the Government side-have opposed these changes publicly and vehemently before and after Budget night, from within the Government.

It is with very great reluctance and with no pleasure whatsoever that we are not opposing these provisions. This is October 1986; it is not October 1975, and we are not threatening Supply to this Government. Oh, no. This Government will get its money. It will get its 30 pieces of silver. It will get it now so that it can go on and attempt, as best it can, to govern this country until the next election that will tip it out. Because of the disquiet we have about this legis- lation, I move now that certain words be added at the end of the second reading, not to defeat the Bill but as an expression of opinion that the Senate condemns the Government for certain actions that it has taken. I move:
At the end of the motion, add: `, but the Senate-
(a) condemns the Government for-
(i) its action in deferring all automatic pension increases due on 1 November 1986;
(ii) its uncaring further 8 month deferral of the poverty traps relief measures;
(iii) its illogical means testing of family allowances for 16 and 17 year olds; and
(iv) its lifting of the rent threshold before a person paying private rent can qualify for rent assistance;
(b) condemns the Government for persisting with its inequitable assets test on pensioners;

(c) strongly protests over the Government's continued assault on veterans and war widows through further restricting access to the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, and freezing the maximum level of social security component where a war widow is also eligible for an aged pension;

(d) calls on the Government to ensure that a voluntary clearance is obtained from the veteran before proceeding with a claim on the veteran's private health insurance, and points out that this aspect of the Bill seeking recompense for veterans' hospital and medical costs constitutes a breach of the fundamental obligation to look after those who served this country in time of war; and

(e) condemns the Government for taking three and a half years to do anything about social security fraud and yet doing nothing new or positive but relying merely on window dressing and public relations'.
I indicate that the Opposition will not oppose the passage of the legislation, but we have nothing but contempt for the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986. Before I comment about and refute some of the claims of Senator Peter Baume, I will briefly speak to what is contained within the legislation. It makes a number of changes in a number of areas. The two important points that Senator Baume stressed were that there will be deferment of the indexation of increases to pensioners and beneficiaries for six weeks and there will be a delay in the implementation of the poverty trap measures until July 1987. Both of those deferral decisions come with no pleasure at all from the Government. In supporting this legislation, I certainly am not barracking wholeheartedly for it at all. In fact it is a very difficult and tough measure, and a very difficult and tough decision was taken by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Even so, it must be said that this decision allows two things. The first is that it contributes to the fiscal responsibility and recovery of this Government in dealing with two enormous problems that confront it-the falling world price of commodities for this country, so we have the tremendous economic challenge that that gave the Government in the month leading up to the Budget, and of course there was the continuing need to reduce the deficit. Both of those have been addressed by the Government, and I think the social security legislation contributes its part to that economic program of the Government. The other important point that needs to be said is that, even despite those two difficult deferral decisions taken under this legislation, there are still other bits of legislation that will redistribute, thus advantaging people under social security. Even within the legislation there is a redistribution of social security dollars to those who are most in need. I will spell out some of them later in my contribution.

It is a tough decision but, unlike Senator Peter Baume, I will not say it is disgusting. One of the things with which this Government has to contend is the economic realities of the world in which it finds itself. Those economic realities are partly due to the falling world commodity prices that I mentioned and partly due to this Government's continuing program to address the mess that was left to it by seven years of Fraser. Let me remind the Senate that when we came into office in 1983 we had to contend with double-digit inflation, double-digit unemployment and a massive deficit. There were many people unemployed in this country. What greater way is there to create poverty than by creating unemployment or doing nothing to address it?

Those things seem to have been cheerfully forgotten by Senator Baume in his contribution today. I can understand why he would forget them. I can understand why he would not like to talk at all about seven years of Fraser. He complains about the delay of this Government in introducing some of its changes. That is because this Government has to address any number of areas that had to be improved or completely fixed up consequent on the disaster left to us by those seven years of Fraser. If poverty traps are something of which the honourable senator has just become aware, where was he during the 1970s when any number of people could have told him about them? Indeed, I would have thought he knew about them, as indeed I think his colleague Senator Fred Chaney knew about them in that time. Yet in those seven years the honourable senator did nothing about them either. We have introduced the legislation, and we have given a date for its implementation. It is a matter of great sadness that there is a deferral of eight months on that poverty traps legislation, for example. But it cannot be ignored that the need for those decisions is not novel. In the seven years of the Fraser Government it did nothing about them. This Government is addressing them.

The other great thing that this Government has achieved, in co-operation with the broad community, is the creation of over 600,000 jobs since it came into office-a quite remarkable achievement that seems to be blissfully and easily forgotten by people on the Opposition benches. There is no greater way of relieving poverty than to create employment and give every Australian an opportunity to take his or her part in the wealth of this country being distributed through wages and salaries. People want to work; people take every opportunity to work. This Government is to be congratulated, as is the public and private sector in co-operation with the Government, for creating over 600,000 jobs that have done so much for people in this country.

The honourable senator says that, for example, there were mean tax arrangements, such as we are funding the defence of the America's Cup or something to do with tax concessions for horse purchases. Indeed those decisions were taken not this year, not in this Budget, but in a previous economic climate. I do not think I would place a high priority on them, but anyone can score cheap points by picking out the two or three items that he wants to hold up against these changes and make mincemeat of us. Why did Senator Baume not tell us about the Medicare legislation that was introduced by this Government? It is the legislation that guarantees medical provision and coverage and no financial disadvantaging to the two million Australians who, it was assessed, were outside the health coverage before Medicare was introduced. Seven years of Fraser and God knows how many medical schemes did not cover two million Australians.

Those people, whether they were pensioners or people other than pensioners, in this country are now guaranteed medical coverage; every Australian is. That is a universal scheme, and it is progressive. People on very high incomes pay into the pot to provide medical coverage in this country very much more than those people on pensions, benefits or low incomes. Why did the honourable senator not talk about that? That is one part of the scheme and, in fact, every one of those pensioners enjoys the benefits of Medicare.

The other great contribution of this Government-again it is in relation to a liability left by Senator Peter Baume's Government-has been the changed provisions under the education portfolio. In both the primary-secondary sector and the tertiary sector this Government is moving as fast as it can and with considerable achievement to provide educational opportunities for a much wider range of people than previously could enjoy them. Again, under seven years of Fraser, spending in education was wound down. We saw the cutback in research funding, capital and recurrent funding to universities so that the number of places on which we were building was even lower than it might have been if we had continued without those seven years of Fraser. Those advantages are there for the pensioners of Australia. Although the provisions and benefits are not directly dealing with their income needs, they are available through this Government's package of policies for all Australians.

I have said before, and I appreciate, that the Government is taking a very difficult step in this legislation. This Government knows full well what track it is on, which is for full economic recovery. Steps should be taken to enable most if not all Australians to take their full place in the community. To do that we need a sound economy, full employment, an educated and skilled work force and research money. I have just spoken to a group of pensioners in King's Hall. They said to me: `Yes, the legislation is tough, but we are prepared to play our part in the ``restraint with equity'' of this Government's program to contribute to the recovery for us all. We know it is tough. We hope the Senate appreciates just how tough it is for us. It is much tougher than for anybody on a wage or salary or any kind of indexed income'. To ask pensioners to do this is very difficult, but pensioners agree that they will take their place in contributing to the recovery. They appreciate that they do have a contribution to make; they appreciate that their part in the consumer needs of this society is not unimportant at all. They do not like to be dismissed in the way that the Opposition so often readily dismisses them. It is very difficult to introduce this legislation, but we do not resile from it because we have a clear understanding of what the Government's focus is.

Senator Peter Baume says, almost with glee, that his Party, if it ever became a government, would remove this Labor Government's assets tests. There goes a certain number of millions of dollars. I understand those opposite, when in government, will consider universal pensions again and will oppose the tax changes that we have introduced. I would like to know how those opposite including Mr Howard, intend to fund all of these wonderful changes. It has been claimed by Mr Howard that he could introduce changes that are assessed at about $5,900m. We hear too that Mr Howard will do away with the deficit; there will be no deficit at all. Mr Howard expects to find $10,000m. I would like to know how he is going to do it. I would like to know what Senator Peter Baume intends to do. He complains about the legislation introduced here, but he proffers no solutions and no alternatives. What are people to do? They cannot possibly choose those opposite when they have nothing to tell them. Honourable senators opposite have no proposals on tax and they are going to do away with medicare that has actually guaranteed medical coverage for two million Australians. That should be very popular. I emphasise that that is said with heavy irony. I think it will be very unpopular. I do not understand how honourable senators opposite are going to pay for all the promises that they keep on making.

It is easy to come in here and complain about this legislation, but what are those opposite proposing to do in its place? What is their proposal for economic recovery? What is their proposal for education and for the creation of jobs? What are their proposals in the tax area? I hear silence from the Opposition. Just before the debate on this legislation was recommenced in this place we had some honourable senators talking about the steel industry. We have had some high words of praise of this Government and indeed of Senator Button, our colleague in this place who has largely had the responsibility for the passage of the improvements in this industry. This Government has encouraged corporations making large profits to consider investment. The previous Government seemed to do none of that. It had seven years to do it; it did not do it. Honourable senators opposite should not tell me that we are not on the right track. They had seven years and they massively fouled it up. They complain about what we are doing, and yet they offer no solutions as to what they might do in the future. I find their arguments totally unconvincing.

Senator Peter Baume has claimed that he is feeling uneasy about accepting tax cuts. Well, a feeling of unease probably makes his breast warm or his heart beat faster. Could he persuade any of his colleagues to oppose that change, or are they all just going to have an uneasy feeling? I would like some more honesty and less uneasy feelings. Honourable senators should look at this legislation. It is important to note that we have the difficulty of those two deferments. When the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) introduced this legislation in the other place, he said:
. . . nothing in this Budget jeopardises our continuing review and reform of the income security system.

I think that is very important. The social security review is well under way. In fact, some of the documentation for that review is now being made available to the public for comment and contribution before the Government takes its final decisions on the proposed changes. Nothing in this legislation will conflict or confuse that continuing review in social security.

The other important areas that I would like to pick up in the time remaining to me are some of the points that I alluded to earlier; that is, the redistribution under this legislation to those most in need. The Government is able to provide the following: additional pension or benefit applicable for a dependent child of a pensioner or beneficiary will be increased by $1 to $17 a week in November 1986; the rate of double orphan's pension will be increased by $4.30 to $60 a month from November 1986; the rate of handicapped child's allowance will be increased by $7 to $92 a month from November 1986; and the rate of mobility allowance will be increased by $1 to $11 a week from November 1986. These are measures that are a cost against government. These are measures, even within this tight economic constraint and time, that the Government is able to provide. The Government has given assistance, albeit small, to those most in need: that is, the children of pensioners or beneficiaries who are, by the previous Government's evidence and certainly by ours, some of the poorest people in this country. The Government has also provided for other measures under this legislation. For example, the compensation arrangements by which sickness benefits are either reduced or recovered will be extended to the invalid pension, unemployment benefit, rehabilitation allowance and sheltered employment allowance. This too will return some revenue to the Government.

The other very significant area is the increase of rent assistance from $10 to $15 a week as from December 1986. We know that the people who are living on pensions or benefits and who have to pay private rental are very disadvantaged, particularly compared with anyone in the community, but certainly against those who have access to public housing. I think it needs to be spelt out again that despite the tough decisions that are taken in this legislation there is also considerable redistribution to those most in need under this legislation. It is, if you like, a redistribution within the social security portfolio, although that is not an entirely accurate way of assessing it.

Other measures are covered in this legislation. The changes in the family allowance for student children between 16 and 18 years of age will be income tested. Families with an income of over $39,000 will not be eligible for family allowance for children between 16 and 18 years of age except under special circumstances. This sometimes leads to people accusing the Government of not appreciating the cost of rearing children. The Government is acutely aware of the cost of rearing children, but it says that people on $10,000 a year or $15,000 a year have a greater need of assistance than those people on $39,000 a year or more. These are very tough times. Those who are better able to pay are being asked to contribute to those who are less able to pay.

This legislation is not totally dreadful as one might be led to believe from what Senator Peter Baume had to say. It is a thoughtful attempt to address a very tough and difficult situation. One needs to examine it very closely. It is an area where I hope the Opposition will not get about its mischievous business of misinformation. Considerable efforts have been taken by the Minister and the Government to ensure that these most disadvantaged in our community are, in these tight economic times, advantaged under this legislation.

Another area which has been brought to my attention and which has caused some difficulty is the proposal for change under the payment of the new Austudy allowance to beneficiaries of social security pensions. Previously people were granted an allowance under the tertiary education assistance scheme along with their pension. That will be changed in the future. It is very important to say that no student pensioner currently enjoying provisions and assistance under TEAS will have that changed during his or her study lifetime. So there will be no changes for pensioners currently on TEAS. The proposed changes affect only those new students coming into the system further down the track-that is, I suppose, no earlier than next year. People do need to be reminded that pensioners, as I say again, currently enjoying TEAS assistance will have no change in that until they finish their studies.

It also needs to be said that any pensioner or beneficiary who is in receipt of a Department of Employment and Industrial Relations formal training allowance, known as an FTA, will not have their pension entitlement changed and the FTA will be paid at a rate of $15 a week for 16- to 20-year-olds, $30 a week for 21- to 24-year-olds and $46.35 a week for those 25 years old and over. The FTA will not be changed under these provisions. Pensioners who are considering studying through this channel need to be reassured on this matter, leaving aside those areas of study that attract the TEAS benefit.

The Government is concerned that a TEAS allowance which has a living component, as does a pension, could be seen as a doubling up provision in relation to public sector payments to people who apply for such benefits and want to study. Certainly, with very limited finances, it is difficult to continue to justify that. I certainly find it very hard to say to pensioners who want to study that in future they will be enjoying a smaller return under TEAS, but we do say that it is a tough economic situation. They will certainly be able to continue to study and of course pensioners will not enjoy any extra charges. They are to be advantaged in that way, so I would hope that no pensioner proposing to study will feel disadvantaged to the point of not wanting to begin or continue that study. They will be eligible for a study allowance of $15 a week and although that is less than pensioners are currently eligible for, it is still an encouragement for pensioners to study and to try to achieve the benefits that study will provide for them. One of those benefits is of course that they are more likely to be employed. They will have a wider range of employment opportunities if they have completed some form of tertiary study or training.

That brings me back to the comments I made at the beginning of this contribution. Yes, it is difficult to delay poverty traps but to consider a proposal to deal with poverty by poverty traps legislation as the be all and end all is to have an insufficient understanding of the way this Government is addressing poverty. Certainly we would like to do more; certainly we would like to make no cuts in current arrangements, but the Government has the view, which I strongly support, that while the alleviation of poverty traps may be of some help, the greatest way out of poverty is through education and employment.

That brings me to another great achievement of this Government, one that of course was completely ignored by Senator Baume. I refer to the Government's child care provisions. The Government has recognised that for many parents, but particularly women, the opportunities to study and to take employment are very limited if there is no provision for child care. It is this Government that has addressed the problem and has provided for the introduction of 20,000 extra child care places over three years. We are in the middle of that three-year period and these extra child care places are currently coming on stream around the country as a result of a variety of provisions, including both full day and occasional care provisions and of course the increase in places under family day care provisions through finances to the States.

The Government knows that the way out of poverty is through employment, through retraining and through education. That is the best way to go. Not only is that of benefit to individuals, not only is it more than likely to relieve them of poverty and provide some real alleviation of poverty, but also it contributes to the increased pool of talents and skills upon which this country can draw. It contributes to increased productivity, creativity and imagination in the country. The alleviation of poverty traps is very necessary and important but it is not and ought not to be seen as the be all and end all. The Government is taking a hard step with this legislation. I say again, though, that the pensioners I have spoken to appreciate the tough times and appreciate their ability to contribute to restraint with equity. No, they do not like it; they do not celebrate it. Neither do we. But in times of economic constraint they are not unprepared to do their bit to contribute to the recovery that is necessary to deal with these changed economic circumstances. In some ways I do not see why we should deny them their contribution, their part in the whole restraint with equity program. Certainly that is their line; I do no more than repeat it. I also place on record, as I have said to those outside in King's Hall and to other pensioner groups I have spoken to, that I and the Government thank them for that willingness to contribute.

I thank also the wage and salary earners in this country who over the last 3 1/2 years have taken cuts in real wages-another point blissfully ignored by Senator Baume in his contribution. It is precisely because of that contribution from wage and salary earners, from pensioners and from dedicated Australians that we are on the road to recovery, that things have turned around considerably since 1983. There are many more jobs, there are more educational opportunities, there is more child care and there are more ways ahead for most of the people of this country. Much still remains to be done and I do not want to sound as though I am satisfied at all with the situation but I do not believe we can take Senator Baume's contribution as the accurate description that he might want it to be seen as. This Government does have a view of where it is going; it does have a view of the contribution that is necessary from all sectors of the community. I commend the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate at the beginning of my speech on the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986-a fairly mild mannered title for a Bill that is going to have such a dramatic effect on so many people-to turn the clock back a couple of years and look at exactly what senior members of this Government said during the 1983 election campaign when they were endeavouring to get the support of large numbers of people, particularly in the welfare sector, in order to get themselves into government. As we go through the years from 1983 to the present, it is interesting to trace the change in the Hawke Government's commitment to the powerless, to the vulnerable and to the poor in Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his election campaign in 1983, under the heading Social Security, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Together with the unemployed, the main victims of Fraserism are those who depend for their income on social welfare payments-the aged, the handicapped, the invalid, the bereaved, the single parents.
It is unforgivable that after seven years of Fraserism a million and a half people on social security are admitted by the Government itself to be living in poverty.
Half of the three million Australians who depend on Government welfare assistance-our aged, our disabled, our invalids, widows and single parents-are on payments below the poverty line.
From his electoral platform he said:
No Labor Government can tolerate that situation.

We are committed to raising over a three-year period the basic pension rate from 22 per cent of average male earnings to which it has fallen under Fraser to 25 per cent. Once we reach that goal we will maintain that 25 per cent proportion by indexation until it is possible to take the pension higher.
Pensions will be adjusted on the basis of the immediately prior six months CPI movement to cut the present lag of four months to one month. Pensioner fringe benefit levels will be indexed.

He went on and on for a full page of glorious rhetoric promising pensioners the earth. In contrast, in 1984, after he had been leading this Labor Government for a couple of years, pensioners and people in poverty were mentioned just twice in 27 pages of election promises and campaign speeches. On page 7 Mr Hawke said that the Government's intentions included:
. . . a concerted effort to attack the causes of poverty and inequality in our midst, to eliminate unemployment and to create a fairer society;
On page 20 he added:

The worst thing that Australian pensioners have to fear-whether they be the ninety-eight per cent totally unaffected by the assets test, or the two per cent who are in some way affected-would be a return to the level of inflation which existed under the Liberals with its devastating impact on their living standards.
But we will do more than just protect the pensioners of Australia from the ravages of renewed inflation.
We will continue to ensure that they all share in the new prosperity.
And specifically, we will continue to work towards the goal of raising the basic pension rate to twenty-five per cent of average weekly earnings.

So to the 1986 Budget and to this Bill which sets out to do a number of things, most of which will effectively make life a lot harder for some already economically disadvantaged individuals and families in the community. It is a Bill which in significant parts pays no attention whatsoever to the level of poverty that exists in Australia, particularly with regard to people who rely entirely on pensions or benefits for their source of income.

Contrary to a view put about by some members of the rabid Right, which is supported by far too many members of the Liberal and National parties congregated in this Parliament, those people who are living in poverty and who are dependent on pensions and benefits of some sort or another are not dole bludgers, nor are they armies of teenage girls trying to turn themselves into millionaires by having a child each year and raising vast amounts of money from the sole supporting parent benefit, although one would think so if one listened to some of the comments made from time to time in the community by people who ought to know better but who are busy playing politics with other people's lives.

The people we are talking about today who will be adversely affected by this legislation include short and long term unemployment beneficiaries of all ages and recipients of the sole supporting parent benefit, the vast majority of whom are women who are suffering from marital breakdown, whose husbands have deserted them and who are left as custodial parents to bring up their children as best they can, often without any assistance by way of maintenance from the non-custodial parent. We are also talking about age pensioners, invalid pensioners, service pensioners, war widows in receipt of a pension and anybody else who was looking forward to the normal promised and expected indexation increase that they were due to receive from 1 November this year.

They have also missed out on a more recent innovation introduced by this Government some months ago and taken away from them under this legislation. I refer to those benefits that they were due to get under the poverty traps legislation-benefits that were intended to help more people get some employment and not suffer as a consequence. They have also been deprived of that benefit. It is worth emphasising at this point that, in moving the indexation increases from 1 November ironically through to Christmas Day, the legislation means a permanent loss-not a temporary one as some people seem to imagine-to the people concerned. Those changes to the date on which indexation will occur are not the temporary ones first indicated by this Government; they are permanent.

Therefore, essentially, this Bill is a cynical and outrageous move by this Government, supported in fact if not in rhetoric by all Opposition members of the parties except the Australian Democrats, which breaks every promise that this Government has ever made to the vulnerable pensioners and beneficiaries who live in Australia. This is done on the very specious grounds that the Budget deficit had to be somewhat cut back in order to placate Wall Street, to make sure that overseas financial gurus did not complain about Australia being turned into a banana republic, to force the dollar up, to bring foreign investment back into Australia and, in so doing, somehow to improve the economy. I suggest that none of the desired results have yet appeared to any great extent. Even if they do, I fail to see how they will particularly benefit pensioners and beneficiaries in this country either in the long term or in the short term.

Senator Crowley had much to say about how improved education, job access and child care are more important than increasing the disposable income of people on pensions and benefits. But I argue how an invalid pensioner, an age pensioner or a war veteran will benefit much from increased access to child care, to full time or part time jobs or to education. In addition, the value of the Australian dollar, if it goes up, will have very little impact on the average pensioner in Australia. Foreign investment in this country is rarely in areas that are labour intensive. It is much more in areas that are capital intensive so, even if there is a massive influx of foreign investment, we cannot guarantee that that will in any way diminish the number of long term or even short term unemployed who are in receipt of benefits and who depend on them as their only source of income.

When the Government talks about improving the economy, it means improving the economy as far as big business is concerned rather than for ordinary Australians. Having said that, I have to say that the Bill does not contain only measures that will be of negative benefit to pensioners and beneficiaries. There are some pluses in the legislation, including things like increases to the double orphan's pension from $55.70 per month to $60 per month-an increase that will not exactly fund them on an overseas trip or a luxurious meal at a high class restaurant. It will increase the handicapped children's allowance from $85 a month to $92 a month. It will increase the additional benefit per child from $16 to $17 per week, which is a rather miserly $1 a week increase. Again, that is hardly something that they will be able to spend on a wildly extravagant celebration. It increases the single intermediate unemployment benefit rate from $88.20 to $91.20 per week as of 1 January next year, and introduces a number of other measures that will mean an improvement in the standard of living and the general state of things for people on pensions. But, as I have indicated, they are increases that I find it hard to get over-enthusiastic about, although I do say that they are probably better than nothing and certainly are better than the sorts of measures handed out in the rest of the legislation to millions of pensioners and beneficiaries. At least I suppose we can say that they are increases, however pitiful they may be.

Almost everything else in the legislation either reduces a benefit or withdraws it. This is being done, notwithstanding the fact that pensioners are falling further and further below the poverty line, as a number of articles in recent months have indicated. The Age of Monday, 22 September, ran an article, complete with chart for graphic demonstration of the facts of what they were saying, headed `Pensions further below poverty line'. The article stated:
When they get their next pension rise, some pensioner families will be $28 further below the poverty line than when the Hawke Government came to power.

After the December increase, pensioner couples with four children will have to live on a payment $69.90 below the poverty line, according to Brotherhood of St Laurence figures. This is about $28 further below the poverty line than in March 1983, when the Labor Government was elected.
A little later the article points out:

For single and married pensioners with children, the gap widens with each extra child. After the December rise, a couple with one child will be $20.40 below the poverty line, or $16.05 further below it than in March 1983.
A couple with two children will be $37.60 below the poverty line, $21.85 further behind than in March 1983. For those with three children, the gap is $53.70, wider by $21.85 . . .
Single-parent pensioners will be $46.50 below the poverty line compared with $29.80 in March 1983, and those with one child will be $29.10 below it, compared with a March 1983 figure of $18.10.

All this is despite the fact that the Government's rhetoric acknowledges the problem, as it did in an item reported in the Adelaide Advertiser earlier this year headed `The ``female face'' of poverty in the 1980s' and quoting the Minister for Social Security, Mr Brian Howe. That article, bylined `Brisbane', stated:
The face of poverty in Australia this decade was overwhelmingly female, according to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Brian Howe.
Mr Howe told the annual general meeting of Civilian Widows that a major challenge was coming to grips with the changing nature of poverty.

I would say that that meeting did not exactly beat that problem and found the challenge somewhat more than it could cope with. If the face of poverty in the 1980s was female when Mr Howe was talking about the matter earlier this year, I believe it is certainly still the case now and a few other faces have been added. Mr Howe went on:

The subordinate economic status of women is reflected in social security, where 77 per cent of payments were to women, 69 per cent of pensioners were women, and 60 per cent of all money was paid to women.
Mr Howe said that the changing nature of poverty had brought with it different needs and different priorities.
To meet these needs the Government was conducting a major review over the next two years.

It is fine and dandy for governments to be conducting reviews into this, that or anything else, but when the Government accompanies those reviews into poverty with the cuts of the sort that we see in this legislation, and when it delays by six weeks or more the normal November indexation increases by putting back the introduction of the poverty trap legislation by eight months, until 1 July next year, one wonders how committed the Government is to improving the lot faced by so many families. I refer to families covering almost 800,000 children, all of whom are living in some way or other below the poverty line. It is all very well for Mr Howe and his Government colleagues to talk about government reviews-major reviews, as he called them-which are to take place over the next two years, when they are accompanied by legislation of the sort we are debating today.

If Opposition members have no more concern for pensioners, the elderly, the sick and the young in our community than the Government appears to have-and they have indicated in this debate that they do not have that concern-those Opposition members should consider not just what will happen to those people in the next few months and beyond but to other sections of the community. I refer in particular to the retail sector, when it is confronted with the loss of some $200m-worth of expenditure which that sector normally would expect from those people in pre-Christmas spending. Pensioners and beneficiaries of all kinds spend, as we all do, more money at Christmas time and similar periods than at any other time of the year. It is at that time that many people living below the poverty line, who have struggled and scraped together some special event money during the year, look forward to the November indexation increases in order to buy a little extra food, something a little special, particularly if they have children, presents and special clothing in order to enjoy, as do the rest of us, a season that is supposed to be festive but which this year may well not be.

As the result of passage of this legislation the shops supplying those goods will be deprived of the custom, and hence the income that is normally supplied by the hundreds of thousands of families on pensions and benefits. One wonders whether the Government or the Opposition have thought of the impact on small businesses which balance leaner times of the year against Christmas spending splurges. That applies not just to those of us who are on reasonable incomes, but to people who save money to spend over Christmas. I have in mind particularly pensioners and beneficiaries who use the November indexation increases to bolster their spending money to improve their lot for that short period of the year when everybody else is celebrating. If the Government chooses to ignore the impact of these provisions on those retailers, on the local small businesses which supply meat, turkeys, chickens, extra fruit and vegetables, even the sweets and puddings, to families who want to enjoy Christmas, I suggest that it shows a callous disregard not only for low income groups but for the businesses and seasonal employees that depend on the spending pattern traditionally produced by the November and early December period.

There is no doubt in my mind that the provisions in this Bill which will implement the cuts to pensioners and beneficiaries and which break the Government's promises on the poverty traps, to say nothing of its promise to increase pensions to 25 per cent average weekly earnings, are among the most iniquitous provisions we have seen for some years, since the Fraser Government tried to starve striking workers back into the work force by depriving their wives and children of food and shelter. That attempt was resoundingly defeated, as it should have been, by the combined Opposition parties. There is no economic or social justification for the action taken by the Government. There is no logic in the Opposition's claim that it cannot oppose this legislation because it will block Supply. Opposition members know that is not true. They know that the Supply Bills are the Appropriation Bills, and they know that in 1981 when the combined Opposition parties defeated part of the Fraser Government's sales tax legislation-to the tune, if I remember rightly, of $250m-the country did not go into the sort of spasm it went into at the end of 1975. There is no connection between the Supply Bills and these Budget Bills. The implication by some Opposition members that there is some connection is a piece of chicanery that they can no longer be entitled to get away with.

The act of delaying legislation of this sort inconveniences the Government a trifle in terms of its deficit. That is no big deal when looking at the deprivation what this legislation will bring to some vulnerable individuals and families. There is no justification for the Government continuing to deny large amounts of money to consolidated revenue by giving, for example, generous tax concessions to some of the largest companies in Australia which are investing off-shore or borrowing billions of dollars on foreign money markets and negatively gearing their interest repayments. There is no justification for the Government's continuing to allow those well-off sectors of the community to use the taxation system to benefit themselves, to deprive Consolidated Revenue and in doing so apparently to force the Government to take this sort of vicious action against the poor, the disabled, the elderly and the vulnerable in Australia. Essentially, the Labor Government and the Liberal Opposition are saying that people do not have to be particularly productive in this country; they do not have to do anything much for Australia's economic development; they only have to be big and powerful. Everyone else, no matter how vulnerable, is open to attack. Both the Government and Opposition parties are allowing this neat anomaly to continue, while crying crocodile tears about the difficulty of getting the economy of this country on its feet without attacking pensioners and beneficiaries.

Gerry Hand, who is, I understand, a member of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, was right when he reportedly said in the Canberra Times of 18 February this year that poverty and homelessness had continued to increase since the Labor Party won power. He said:
. . . the cost of putting economics before social justice has led to a continuing erosion in the real value of some social welfare pensions.
I do not believe that we have adequately addressed the claims of those demanding increased social justice.

Nor do I. Mr Hand went on to advocate giving pensioners and other beneficiaries increases about the level of indexation, perhaps, for example, through a form of growth dividend. Not only did the Government not do that, but it also did the reverse. Mr Hand added:
1986 is the year in which I believe the Federal Labor Government must bite the bullet and take up the claims for greater social justice.

In this piece of legislation we have seen just how this Government has chosen to ignore that bullet. Not only has the Government not bitten on it, but the Government has also sent it in the direction of people who are already hard hit by the treatment they have received in the last three years under this Government.

Finally we come to the Opposition's pathetic amendment-an attachment that it wishes to move to the second reading motion. The Opposition's deliberate complicity with this Government in ensuring that this legislation was brought on for debate by agreeing to delay until Thursday or some later date, debates that we were currently engaged in, has ensured that the Government will get its legislation in place by the date that it wants it-that is, 1 November. The Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion condemns the Government for its action in deferring all automatic pension increases due on 1 November 1986. It also condemns the Government for incurring a further eight months deferral of poverty trap relief measures. It condemns the Government for its illogical means testing of family allowances to 16- and 17-year-olds. It also condemns the Government for its lifting of the rent threshold before a person paying private rent can qualify for rent assistance. If the Opposition is as outraged as it says it is by these moves, it should join us in opposing the relevant clauses.

There is not much point in the Opposition's condemning the Government for a move which it is supporting. There is not much point in getting up in this House-as Senator Peter Baume did-and talking about the way in which the hides of various unfortunate individuals in this country are being attacked by certain clauses in this legislation when the Opposition could save the hides of those people by simply opposing the offending clauses. Senator Peter Baume talked about the fact that veterans had risked their lives for this country and were receiving as a reward for that the miserable and unnecessary cuts embodied in this legislation. Yet the Opposition is not even prepared to risk a minor increase in the deficit to repay those veterans who will be affected by this legislation. I repeat: If the Opposition is so outraged by these moves, it should join us by opposing the relevant clauses. This is not blocking a Budget in any way at all, it is an expression of genuine concern for and commitment to a vulnerable group of people in this country.

There is a word for people who say one thing and do another and the Liberal-National Party senators in this place have earned that sobriquet over and over again this session by complaining about the damage that is being done to one sector or another of this community by one piece or another of this Government's legislation. Yet they have done nothing at all to prevent the implementation of that legislation and nothing at all to prevent the tremendous effects that some of the legislation will have on some very vulnerable sections of the Australian community.

I think the problem for pensioners is acute everywhere in Australia, but it is particularly so in the larger cities. It is particularly acute in my home city of Sydney, which is probably the most expensive place in Australia to live. Pensioners in Sydney survive. That is about the best one can say for their present situation. They look forward to indexation increases. Every bit of money that comes into their hands means a little more food and a few more necessary items. Pensioners are now living in conditions which should be considered absolutely intolerable and totally unjustified in any decent, civilised community. Every night thousands of people sleep in parks and shops. I am not speaking of drop-outs and people of that kind but of people on pensions, older men and women who simply cannot afford to live anywhere else.

In Sydney the rental situation and the shortage of accommodation has now reached the stage where it is almost impossible to get any kind of accommodation at reasonable prices. The welfare agencies do their best. They provide basic survival sustenance and somewhere to sleep for thousands of people, but even they are up against it. The Smith Family or any such agency will tell us that, especially during winter, the problem is acute. Where accommodation is available in inner Sydney, it is often very bad accommodation. A single wretched room with shared facilities can cost a very large sum of money-$40 or $50. These places are often fire traps, as has been proved by the number of tragic fires in recent years in Sydney. People have to live in these fire traps, and a number of pensioners have been killed in them-that is a matter of record-because they cannot afford to live anywhere else.

I take the view on behalf of my constituents-I put it to the Government again-that the whole rent assistance area needs to be looked at very carefully. The only real way to provide assistance is not through a complicated form or arriving at the maximum figures-even though the poverty trap provision before us is an improvement, I do not think it goes far enough-but by indexing rent assistance to the cost of living, to the average rental cost in various cities. This could be done, and it would provide equality for people all over Australia. It would make a tremendous difference to people who need this assistance badly. Every cent, every 10c and every 50c is important to them. They are gradually being pushed further and further down in the poverty area. As the shortage of rental accommodation, now the worst since the war in Sydney-the vacancy factor is the lowest it has been for decades-worsens, these problems also will worsen.

I am aware that the Minister is listening to me with some compassion. I know that he personally sees and feels these things in the administration of his own portfolio. I do not know how he gets on in Cabinet with these measures. Perhaps the Government felt that it had to take this money, but I ask him to go back to it and to say that this is not an area in which it is fair and reasonable to be taking money from people. If only all members of Parliament could understand and appreciate the enormous suffering and hardship and the early deaths that result from the reduction in living standards of people who have only the pension and its associated benefits to rely on, I believe we would not be debating this Bill now. I do not think it would ever have come before us.

I talk to various people from time to time in organisations that help pensioners. One is the drop-in centre in William Street in Kings Cross. That is an excellent organisation which provides facilities for older people. It provides meals and some kind of assistance, within the legal limits. I find that the old people who go to such places are terribly grateful for it. There are other old people in Sydney who simply cannot afford to buy decent meat, fruit, milk and things of that kind. There is no question of their being able to buy those things. They live on bread and tea. Any of us who know the science of geriatrics knows that geriatric symptoms are advanced by a bad diet. I think we are doing a very poor service for people who may have worked well for this country all of their lives when we force them to that kind of situation. The Minister, as a doctor of medicine, would probably appreciate and understand that there is some truth in what I say. It is a dietary matter and it is important that people should not be pressed into a situation in which they cannot afford the right food.

People I have talked to in these places-I have no other evidence, but it is probably true-have told me that old people do buy pet food. They buy it because it is the only source of food protein they can afford. I have heard it said that as much as 60 per cent of certain brands of pet food in Sydney is sold to old people for human consumption. I remind honourable senators that it is Australia in 1986 that we are talking about.

Today in this country over 2.8 million people, including some 800,000 children, live in poverty. They are forced to miss meals and have inadequate diets. Children miss school because they do not have respectable clothing to wear there. These people cannot afford to use heaters in winter. They go without medical treatment, especially dental and eye care and, when they go for treatment, they cannot afford medicines. Their isolation is increased because they cannot afford transport. They rely on charity or emergency relief for day to day living. They face eviction and homelessness. This is increasingly the case in Sydney. People are evicted because they cannot pay rents, and they can find nowhere else. To add to the indignity and show the ultimate in poverty, families break down through financial and emotional stress and force children to be put out to institutional care. What kind of society is this that does nothing for these people?

These are the circumstances of the poor in our society, and so many of the poor are the people who will be affected by this Bill, which we are hastening through. It is a situation which the Government and the Opposition, through their collusion-I agree with what Senator Haines said earlier; they are colluding to pass this Bill-are exacerbating.

The poverty trap measures are very good. The cost is not enormous. The total cost of these changes in 1986-87 is $140m. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his second reading speech on the poverty traps legislation, said:

First, it will leave more money in the pockets of hundreds of thousands of people on social security with some private income. Secondly, it will ease the transition from welfare to work for people, such as supporting parents, who are temporarily out of the permanent paid work force. Thirdly, it will provide an incentive to all people on social security to provide for themselves, either through part time work or investments . . . In particular, these reforms will concentrate on groups of special concern to the Government-the aged, children in poverty, particularly in sole parent families, and pensioners and the unemployed renting in the private market.

Not in any spirit of malice, Mr Deputy President, but with some sorrow and regret I recall to the Government its Minister's own words. These are the people of whom he said so recently needed so much from the Government; these are the people he now proposes to deprive.
