Also the Government has backed tax cuts, or we think it has, but they have not arrived yet. One cannot rely on this Government for anything until it has occurred.

If one has a job one is right. But if one is a pensioner one had better watch out. On the very day on which recommendations of the Government's social security review are being announced in the papers, in this place we are debating the social security cuts. That report recommends that the Government pay a supplement to the basic family allowance to people with one or more children under six years. It recommends that the family allowance be increased to those with four or more children. It says that the Government should increase family allowances in line with the consumer price index. Indeed, Professor Cass said that people without children have an adjusted average income that is $6,200 higher than that of families with children. While that report has come out stressing the need for more support for families, this Government has decided to tax the people and take away their family allowances unless they are means tested and the income of those people is below a certain level.

We are not the only ones who are objecting. Senator Coates sent out a letter, the terms of which were pretty strong. I will be very interested indeed to see how that particular senator votes in this place when the vote is taken. He said:
The poor will fall further into poverty under the Keating Budget.
He continued:

I had been dreading the Budget, but did not expect it to contain some of the appalling decisions . . . I expected more widespread cut-backs than there were and I expected them in areas which also affected the better-off people in our society.
Regrettably the rumoured welfare cuts were there, but the only item to bother the wealthy was a 10 per cent increase in sales tax for luxury cars.
The millions of dollars which go to private schools and to the America's Cup defence, for instance, were unaffected.
So I cannot accept that the burden is being shared equally let alone equitably as promised.
Senator Coates made very strong accusations about the Government's Budget. As I said, I will be following very closely his movements when we vote on the motion.

Senator Crowley, in her usual way, blamed the Fraser Government. She said it was all our fault that the present Government has to take this action. Let us look at what we did. Indeed, let us look at the balance of payments figure. For the year just gone it was $13,713m. The figure for the new quarter was the highest on record. I wonder what the new year will bring. When we left office the balance of payments figure was $6,757m. There is a little difference! Senator Crowley said that it was all our fault. This Government has wrecked our balance of payments, not the Fraser Government. Under this Government the average time a person is unemployed is 52 weeks; when we left office it was 32 weeks. When we left office the Australian dollar was worth 207 yen. What is it now? We were told that it would not fall below the 100 yen mark. But with this Government anything could happen, and it certainly has. the Australian dollar is down now. I am not sure what it is. It is now worth something like 95 or 96 yen.

When we were in government a man on average weekly earnings was paying in tax 22.9 per cent of his total earnings. What will he be paying after the tax cuts? He will be paying 24.9 per cent. That is the tax on the average weekly earnings of a man without dependent children. Let us look at the figures for a man with dependent children. When we left office he was paying 14.1 per cent; after the tax cuts he will be paying 17.6 per cent. This Government has increased taxes to such an extent that the tax cuts we hear so much about will still not take people down to the percentage of their income that they were paying when we left office.

What has happened to Australia's credit rating? Senator Crowley said it is all our fault, all the Fraser Government's fault, that this Government has had to make these disastrous cuts. I will tell honourable senators what has happened to the credit rating. We had a triple A credit rating under the Fraser Government. Under this wonderful Treasurer, who has just missed out on the wooden spoon for the worst damage a Treasurer could possibly do to his country's economy, it is now down to a double A credit rating. That is the sort of thing that this Government has done. This is the reason why it now says: `We have got to do something'. We are in such a critical position that it is like a country at war. The Government has decided to do these things-to delay the pension, to cut the war widows incomes and the family allowances.

The Australian Democrats have said that we should be supporting them in voting against this legislation. This is a Budget Bill; it is, indeed, a money Bill. The Democrats promised they would never vote against such a Bill. Of course, they have done that so many times now that it is quite commonplace. Their promises no longer mean anything. The real reason behind their opposition and their anger for our not supporting them is that they so desperately need a double dissolution to survive. If they do not get a double dissolution, if they do not reach the situation where they can get less of a percentage vote to get back into the Parliament than they do under a normal half Senate election, their numbers will certainly be decimated. That is the real reason why they are so angry that we are not supporting them. That is the real reason, once again, why they are breaking their promises.

I would like to turn to the subject of veterans. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) may be able to help me. The Minister did tell me that he would be speaking in this debate. He said that he would apologise to me. He has not, as yet, spoken and I do not see him on the speakers list. I am not sure whether the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) is going to apologise on his behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will certainly speak in the Committee stage.

—I look forward to his apology in the Committee stage. I would like to clarify exactly what has happened in the media fairly recently. If we read page 136 of the Senate Hansard of 20 August, we find that the Minister incorporated a statement. The statement is signed by the Secretary to his Department, Mr D. Volker. Paragraph 6 (c) of that statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: War Widows pension granted after 1 November 1986 to a service or social security pensioner
The rate of service or age pension will be reduced to $60.05 a week if already being paid at a higher rate, otherwise pension will continue at the lesser rate in payment.
I very foolishly believed the Minister. I then went into print. In my news release-a part that affects this area-I said:

The war widow who is a veteran in her own right will not only have her service pension frozen, but indeed from 1 November newly eligible war widow veterans will lose $42 of their service pension and will receive the same total pension as a war widow who is not a veteran.

I thought that was pretty mean and pretty despicable on the part of the Government. When the Minister for Veterans' Affairs incorporated that statement it assured me that that must be right. I was then abused by the Minister over the next couple of days. In a letter to the Mercury, he said:

I can also assure your readers that, contrary to Senator Walters' comments (Mercury, September 9), newly eligible war widows who are service pensioners in their own right before November 1 will not lose any part of that pension.

Honourable senators might consider that to be fairly confusing. After all, I only accepted what the Minister and his Secretary had said. I wrote back to the paper and quoted exactly what the Minister had put in the Senate Hansard of 20 August. The Minister and his Department did not have the decency to write back and say: `We were wrong'. I had an hilarious time talking to some of the officers of the Parliament as they, no doubt, will verify. I read that over to them and they said: `Oh, that is not the way you are meant to read it'. I said: `How else are you meant to read it?' They said: `Yes, I can see how confusing it would be'. I said: `It is not a bit confusing. It is stated very clearly'. It said, in words of virtually one syllable:
The rate of service or age pension will be reduced to $60.05 a week if already being paid at a higher rate . . .

I thought that was very clear but the officers kept telling me that it was all very confusing and not clear at all. They were not for saying that they had made a mistake. Indeed, nobody was for saying that there was a mistake. I eventually saw the Minister and asked whether he would give me an apology. I am looking for an apology because my credibility back home is at stake. He has assured me that I was right and that he was wrong. I stress that the buck stops with the Minister, and I hope that he will say so. In this debate I look forward to that.

The fact that war widows are being attacked at all is a great disappointment to me. Every Government has promised veterans that they will be looked after on their return or, if they do not return, their widows and families will be looked after by the taxpayers of this country. Every Government has stood by that and has supported veterans and their families, but this Government has now attacked war widows and is freezing the age pension for war widows receiving the war widows pension. That is not something that should be done to the war widows of this country.

There is so much one can say about the area of social security. The Government has not kept its promises to the people, to the pensioners. The Government has made extravagant promises including that old chestnut, the one that keeps coming up, that pensions will reach 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Government has trotted out all these promises. Senator Short referred today to all those promises to entice pensioners to vote for the Government, but when it is returned the promises are not fulfilled. The Government has promised that it will look after disadvantaged groups, but that promise is never fulfilled. It has promised to look after the families, but of course that has never been fulfilled. Since this Government has been in power the dependent spouse rebate has not been increased. Under us it more than doubled, from $400 in 1975 to $830 for a spouse without dependent children, and even more-$1,030-for a beneficiary with dependent children. This Government has not increased the family allowance, it has only taken it away from certain categories. We increased the family allowance on two occasions. It is typical of this Government and typical of the Prime Minister that the number of promises he makes to get into government is one thing and the number of promises carried out is another. Unfortunately no promises have been carried out; there has been only great detriment to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt in the minds of any of us who have a sincere interest in social security and the welfare of those who are most dependent upon the Government that this Government has been faced with a delicate balancing act, required, as it was, to produce a deficit which would satisfy the domestic corporate sector and the international money market while at the same time ensuring that those whose welfare depends most directly on social welfare benefits were not put at a disproportionate disadvantage. Senator Short and other Opposition speakers may well criticise what they perceive to be unfair, inequitable and distorted priorities. I venture to suggest that in the same circumstances other decisions, far less well considered, would have been made if the current Opposition when in power were faced with the same range of options. From what I have been able to gather from the Press over the few weeks since the Budget was announced, supporting mothers seem to be the favourite target of those on the far Right who currently have the luxury of not having to make the difficult decisions and also have the good fortune to be able to make all their vituperative remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also very interesting to note that in those few weeks since the Budget, very little emphasis has been given by the coalition to the reductions of which the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986 is the legislative instrument. We have heard a great deal of hysteria about various types of taxes such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. I admit that these taxes are principally, though not solely, the concern of people on higher incomes. There has been a great deal of emphasis on tax cuts, which are expected by the vast majority of our earning population, and the Government's integrity seems to rest on those tax cuts being brought into effect on 1 December. I have no doubt that will be the case. However, the Opposition seems to have waited until this Bill has come before the Parliament to make any substantial contribution to the debate on how we are going to redistribute resources which total considerably less than we would have wished. Most of us find it unpalatable to postpone the indexation of age and other pensions for three pension days. That medicine has been marginally easier to take because we have also determined that the indexation will not be discounted. This would have been a far more difficult decision and a more harmful decision as far as most pensioners are concerned. The savings achieved as a result of that deferment for three pension payment periods will be directed towards families in greatest need and those, as we are all very well aware by now, are families with young children. I recall that during the taking of evidence by one of the Committees on which we serve a very valuable contribution was made by the New South Wales representatives of the Australian Pensioners League emphasising that pensioners were concerned for their own welfare; they were concerned to see their pensions increased to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings but they were also aware of the fact that it was families with young children which were in much greater need and, if asked to nominate a priority, they would have held that group up as the most deserving. Every fair-minded person must deeply regret that our measures to ease the heavy marginal tax rates currently levied on pensioners' extra earnings have had to be postponed but none of this affects the major commitment of this Government to review and reform the income security system. It is a source of great satisfaction to me that we have in our hands now Issues Paper No. 1 of the Social Security Review being conducted by Dr Bettina Cass. This particular paper is entitled `Income Support for Families with Children' and I strongly recommend it to all honourable senators who take a genuine interest in this vital subject.

The fact that one of the measures included in this legislation is the income test on family allowances has been mentioned on a number of occasions. That income test is a very generous one. It applies to families with an income of $39,000 a year and over. It does not take the family allowance away from needy families, as Senator Walters seemed to assume. That is a rather inaccurate interpretation. We have been aware over the years that there are families who are not as dependent on the family allowance as others. That decision was not an easy one to make, but in the discussion paper that has now been made available to us it is one of the issues that is very thoroughly analysed. The family allowance and the issue of horizontal and vertical equity have been very thoroughly examined.

Suggestions are made of a more targeted approach to ensure that adequate family allowance is targeted to those families most in need. The targeted approach that Dr Cass seems to advocate recognises the increased needs of families with one or more pre-school age children. Of course, as we know, this frequently coincides with the period in the family life cycle that is marked by relatively low incomes and a low level of mothers' work force participation or the extra cost of child care where both parents are employed. The discussion paper includes statistical information that makes it very clear that families without children are far more likely to be in economically comfortable circumstances than those with young pre-school children.

Horizontal equity is interpreted as a principle that requires that people in like circumstances should be treated alike. To achieve horizontal equity, it is advocated that we look at a number of approaches such as a basic family allowance payment; a young child family supplement where there are one or more children under the age of six, making provision for that family where the mother's capacity to enter the work force is greatly reduced; a large family supplement-which would better be phrased as a supplement for large families; the introduction of an income tested disabled child's allowance rather than the range of measures now available for families with disabled children; and indexation of all elements of the family allowance payments.

The paper also looks at ways in which vertical equity can be introduced into this system. Vertical equity is the principle that requires that people on low incomes should receive greater assistance and/or pay less tax than those on higher incomes, that is, according to the capacity to pay. To provide this equity we will consider a range of options including higher rates of additional pension or benefit and family income supplement for teenage children not yet old enough to be eligible for education allowances. We will need to address the increased costs incurred by low income families who must depend on private rental accommodation. There is plenty of evidence in this volume and elsewhere to prove that those people who are on low incomes and also dependent on private rental accommodation are at a double disadvantage. We could also look into integrating additional pensions and benefits and family income supplements into one low income family supplement to be paid to the parent primarily responsible for the children. All of the arguments in this section of the document emphasise that crucial element of targeting money to the parent primarily responsible for the children and that payments should be made regularly and not at too long intervals. It is suggested that such integration may improve the take-up of the family income supplement by low income families in the work force, and support parents in their transition to work. We are well aware of the fact that the family income supplement has not been taken up to the extent to which we believe there are people in the community who are probably eligible for it.

That targeting and perhaps providing phase-in periods between unemployment and employment also associated with the family income supplement are other measures that have been advocated in this excellent discussion paper. We would like to see an increased rate of additional pension or benefit and family income supplement and a higher rate of payment where there is a teenage child. Increasing rent assistance to pensioners, the amalgamation of the additional pension or benefit and family income supplement and an indexation of all income tested additional payments for children are measures that are also advocated.

It is absolutely clear that the Opposition simply has not given any thought whatsoever to measures that should be taken-measures of this nature that would be directed very carefully and very clearly to those who are in greatest need. As a result of the publication of this discussion paper, we have become aware that our system of social benefits is badly wanting in comparison with those of other industrialised countries which aspire to the same standard of living as we have in Australia. We have the unpleasant distinction of being third from the bottom of those countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development in terms of our assistance to families. In fact our payments for second and subsequent children compare very poorly indeed.

I hesitate to upset Senator Walters again by referring to this, but I must insist that one of the elements that has contributed without a doubt to our having fallen so badly behind other countries is the lack of indexation of the family allowance during the late 1970s and early 1980s. Of course, this has meant a very severe drop in the value of those payments, which in many families are absolutely essential to maintain a decent standard of living. In Senator Walters's words, interference is exactly what our social security system needs and not the sort of ad hoc piecemeal approach not only of the last few years or decades but of the decades since the early part of this century when Australia led the world in social security arrangements for those in need of support from the public purse.

Of course, what we need are changes that are carefully designed as a result of the review now under way. Some rationalisation has already begun. Simultaneously with the Budget decisions we have announced a range of measures to tighten the administration of the unemployment benefit to ensure greater fairness in the allocation of limited funds. We have now made it a prerequisite that all unemployment beneficiaries will have to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service to qualify for the benefit as from November 1986. This will have the effect of removing the unhelpful comparisons that have been made in the past between those people registered for unemployment and those registered for social security benefits. There has been a tendency to compare apples with cheese, if I may say so, in the past. That has been a completely unsatisfactory state of affairs. It has been possible for some rather mischievously minded people to suggest that far more people were receiving social security benefits than were registered for employment. Being able to bring that data into line will provide us with a far more accurate picture of what the situation really is and will do away with the opportunity for people who have a mind to do so to aim a few more hefty but completely unwarranted kicks at those people in the community who are reliant upon public assistance of one sort or another.

The changes that are being brought in at this stage are unpalatable and most of us would have preferred them not to have been necessary. We believe that the way in which they have been brought about with the redirection of savings towards families with young children, those on lowest incomes, is correct. This is just the first step in what we believe will be a thorough overhaul of our social security system. We have the sincere intention of introducing equity so far as possible into what until now has been a haphazard system. It will direct assistance to the neediest at the time in their lives when they are most in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1986. Senator Giles referred to the difficulty of taking this medicine and said that it was unpalatable for all. When I was a small child and had to take rather nasty tasting medicine, my mother's advice was always to do it quickly-to take it, get it over with, so that the taste would not linger. Let us make no mistake about it, what we are doing here is dishing out the nastiest medicine of the Budget; the real nasties are in this Bill. SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon, in common with many other senators, I met a group of pensioners from my State of Victoria who are here in Canberra in a futile attempt, unfortunately, to make politicians see the injustice of what is happening. I asked them, because I had spoken with them earlier in the day and had got quite a different message, whether they were the pensioners to whom Senator Crowley had been speaking. Those pensioners have asked me to place on record the fact that they were astonished at being told that the Opposition had colluded with the Government to remove business that was before the Senate in order that this legislation should be rammed through while those pensioners are in Canberra attempting to put their case.

The major elements of this legislation to which I refer are, of course, the deferral of the consumer price index increases for pensions and fringe benefits, sickness and unemployment benefits to December, and deferral of the operation of the poverty traps legislation to next July, as well as the increased thresholds for supplementary rent assistance. As Senator Haines outlined earlier, this represents a litany of broken promises made by the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his Australian Labor Party policy speech in 1983. Indeed, we should have seen this sort of thing coming when, in his policy speech at the next election, in 1984, in 27 pages of policy speech pensioners and people in poverty were mentioned only twice. Indeed, they seemed then to be slipping down the political agenda.

It is important to recognise the Government commitment, which was part of the tax reform package, aimed at easing poverty traps. Perhaps there was some comfort for people in poverty to realise that the Parliament was at last recognising the enormous difficulties under the system as then constituted, and indeed as it still will be for an extended period, involved in working their way out of poverty. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. As we are talking about the Government's tax package, the Government's raison d'etre almost since the most recent election, we should look at what is being done in this legislation compared with the tax cuts. Part of the collusion between the Government and the Opposition to get this legislation before us today has involved the adjournment of the debate on the Income Tax Rates Bill 1986-I might add, halfway through my speech on that Bill. That Bill will have the effect of reducing income tax rates at the top level from 60 per cent to 49 per cent, and to lower the rates from 48 per cent to 40 per cent, from 46 to 40, 30 to 29, and 25 to 24 per cent by July 1987. It has been argued that high income tax rates must be lowered because they are unfair and serve as a disincentive. It is left to the Democrats to put the case of pensioners and beneficiaries, those who live below the poverty line. For every dollar that those people earn over the miserably low permissible income level, which will stay that low, they suffer a penalty of 75c in the dollar-50c lost from their pension or benefit for every dollar earned, and 25c in the dollar taxation. That is an effective 75 per cent tax rate.

SPEECH.PARA: I have with me a piece of paper containing some mathematics given to me by one of the pensioners with whom I spoke today. She points out that she receives a pension of $102.10 a week and has a `massive' amount of capital of $5,000 invested at 11.75 per cent. But because of that investment at that not particularly high interest rate, she has a minimal $10.30 addition to her pension because of the operation of that effective very high marginal income tax rate. That is an individual case of someone who is obviously not well off. It seems that we operate on a double standard. For those in employment, for business people and people on high incomes it is seen as unfair and a disincentive that they should have to contribute at the level of 46 per cent, 48 per cent or 60 per cent; so these levels are being lowered. Meanwhile we close our eyes to the situation of the poor who will still suffer an effective 74 per cent penalty, even after the tax cuts.

We should not forget either that the abolition late last year of the earnings concession arrangements by which some pensioners were able to average their incomes over one year, rather than only a few weeks, has added a further discrimination. This is especially so now that this Budget, quite rightly, allows sports people, performing artists and others such as authors and inventors to average their incomes over five years. Pensioner groups have been doing some work which suggests that the tax-free threshold would need to be about $8,000 before this iniquitous effective marginal tax rate, which rips off people with a miserly $5,000, above the pension to invest stopped biting. My Australian Democrat colleagues and I-and, I expect, most other senators-are increasingly coming across cases of quite elderly pensioners, often over 80 years, who this year for the first time in their lives as pensioners have to pay tax. We should address this issue because it is certainly a double standard.

Also in this Budget session the Opposition and the Government have joined together to add to the burden of people such as the pensioners by imposing sales tax on foodstuffs in the form of milk and fruit juice. Only the Democrats opposed this iniquitous move. We stood by our resolve that the necessities of life should not be taxed. We do not believe that this Budget has imposed restraint with equity. There is nothing equitable about asking people below the poverty line to accept further burdens while we lower the contribution asked of the comfortably off and those in employment and let takeover merchants off scot-free.

Let us look at company tax. It is interesting that there is no significant change in the overall tax mix this year. In particular, company tax receipts will continue at around 10 per cent of the total tax revenue. By contrast, about 10 years ago company tax provided about 20 per cent of total tax receipts. It is noteworthy that the revenue obtained last year from company tax fell more than $350m below the Government's predictions. There are some questions to be asked here about whether there is sufficiently vigorous enforcement of the laws in place in this area.

Through the kind of action which the Government and the Opposition jointly propose and support today, we ignore and exacerbate the most disgraceful social problem in Australia today-the increase in poverty. Let us look again at the 1983 Australian Labor Party policy speech. It contains fine words and fine sentiments. Sentiments such as:
Together with the unemployed, the main victims of Fraserism and those who depend for their income on social welfare payments-the aged, the handicapped, the invalid, the bereaved, the single parents.
It is unforgivable that after seven years of Fraserism a million and a half are people admitted by the Government to be living in poverty.
That figure is now two million. The policy speech continued:
No Labor Government can tolerate this situation.

Would that that were so. Let us look at the facts. As I said, there are now more people below the poverty line and those people are further below the poverty line and falling. As we noted earlier in the year, before the Budget, when community groups with concern for these facts attempted to influence the Government's decision on the Budget, they brought to our attention that in fact 2.5 million people were living below the poverty line and that, of those, almost 800,000 were children. The pleas organised through the Australian Council of Social Service in that pre-Budget campaign fell, unfortunately, on deaf ears. Instead we got a doctrine of restraint with equity.

It is also interesting to note that the proportion of government spending on social security has fallen since 1983. That is a fact which does not sit very well with those campaign promises of 1983. ACOSS said:
Cuts of the kind being proposed-
and of course today it is cuts of the kind that are proceeding through this Parliament-
are economically counterproductive and socially unjust.

I remind the Senate again of the consequences, as outlined by my colleague, Senator Haines, in this pre-Christmas period. It is almost an indictment of us that apparently the only thing that might stir some of us into action is the fact that many businesses will lose a great deal in a period when they usually make a lot of money from people in low income brackets who spend most of what they receive on surviving during the year and who, at Christmas, dig very deeply into their pockets so that they can enjoy the festive season with everyone else. This year will not be festive for those people.

Even the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) recognised in his own pre-Budget lobbying period this increase in poverty. In fact, earlier in the year he actually drew attention to the changing face of poverty. Poverty is increasing, deepening and being feminised. This is a matter of great concern to me. Mr Howe said:
In Australia in the 1980s the face of the poor is most likely to be a woman's face.
That is a matter of enormous concern. We should take entirely the opposite actions to those that are being taken in this legislation this week.

The Salvation Army has also reported the same sorts of changes in the patterns of poverty. As it said, once it was considered that the poor were the old, the destitute and the lonely, but now the faces of the poverty stricken belong to young women and their children and to young unemployed men. The Salvation Army points out that women are turning to it very often because they are trying to escape from domestic violence. Again, very often that violence occurs because of unemployment which leads to demoralised family breadwinners being unable to cope. The Salvation Army points out that other women are coming to that organisation because they are unmarried or separated with children and they cannot exist on social security payments any longer. Demand for the Salvation Army's family welfare services increased by 15 per cent last year. These facts were put by the Salvation Army's Colonel Bath in the Weekend Australian in June this year. Because people cannot live on social security payments any longer, the stresses and strains on our voluntary welfare organisations are enormous. Those organisations are telling us that they cannot cope any longer either. What we are doing here today is definitely of no help to them. Not only is poverty deepening, increasing and being feminised but people are also staying in poverty for longer. The poverty traps legislation was a recognition that something needed to be done about this; yet today we are debating a Bill which will just cement people more and more deeply into poverty. TALK.START.PARA: —In this same document the National Council for the Single Mother and Her Child and Community Child Care (Vic.) makes some important points on the effect of this Budget on single parent families. It points out that pensioners and beneficiaries with children already suffer from the lack of indexation in the system. Most pensioners with children therefore must supplement their social security income with other earnings. The postponement of this legislation to enable pensioners to earn more will make a significant difference to those people. It is perhaps most distressing, having spoken with families who are in this group, that the impact of this, which we are seeing consistently and unfortunately now increasingly, is that these people are accused of abusing the system, but in many ways they have little choice. For a mother with children, when it means the difference between feeding them and not feeding them or between being able to send them on school excursions and not, it is perhaps excusable that such women very often become a part of the cash economy. They suffer not just from abuse from the much more well-heeled section of the community but also from their own conscience, because no mother wants to be seen as a law-breaker in the eyes of her children. I have great empathy with those women because I do not particularly like to be a law-maker who may be seen to be involved in the sorts of things in which we are involved with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Council for the Single Mother and Her Child points out, as I have done earlier today, that wage earners are doing much better out of this Budget than people who are on pensions and benefits. Indeed, wage earners have enjoyed an estimated increase in real disposable income of 7.3 per cent in the 10 years from 1976-77 to 1986-87, while the disposable income of a supporting parent with two children has declined by 2 per cent over the same period.

One of the aspects of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill which will be increased is the children's allowance, which is being raised by $1 per week. The point that is made, quite justifiably, in this document by these groups is that this is highly unrealistic and effectively a non-action, considering the extent of its inadequacy. The cost of rearing children is estimated to be about $38 per week per child, but that varies according to the age of the child. This $1 increase hardly compensates for the severity of other measures in the Budget, some of which I have outlined, including the imposition of a sales tax on food items such as flavoured milk and fruit juices, which form a large part of an essentially nutritious diet in families of all kinds.

I found it rather incredible to hear Senator Giles say earlier in the debate that New South Wales pensioners have said that they accept the cuts they are suffering because they realise that families with children need the money more than they do. That may be true, but the truth of the matter is that Australia's record of support for children has now been shown to be abysmal, as Senator Giles then went on to point out. She referred to the social security review which was referred to in an article in the Age this morning, which shows Australia to be above only two other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in the support we give to families with children. It is important that the Government does not allow-certainly the Australian Democrats will not allow-age pensioners to believe that their sacrifice, the sacrifice which we will be imposing on them in the legislation we are debating here today, is in the cause of ensuring that families with children are better off.

As we have pointed out, the beneficiaries of all this sad farce in which we are involved are those in employment who have a much more comfortable existence and who are getting tax cuts; people in business whose contribution to the tax mix is going down; people involved in money making procedures such as company takeovers and using negative gearing to write off their tax liabilities-on and on goes the list. The attitude to all of this of Government and Opposition senators and members in the other place is rather astonishing. We have had protestations from people on both sides, members and senators, saying that they think this legislation is unworthy, unfair and unjust. We have had a suggestion that indeed pensioners should take legal action to remove the injustice that is about to be placed upon them. This call was indeed cruel in its futility. It is the Parliament which has the responsibility for this action. Indeed, should anybody have taken up the suggestion, it certainly would not be successful in the courts. It seems to me to be an astonishing sort of reaction from a so-called responsible parliamentarian.

The Government has been called hypocritical by the Opposition in all of this exercise. Surely the same epithet could be laid upon the Opposition when, for all its protestations, all it really has to do, if it believes this is the sort of legislation which should not pass, is join the Australian Democrats and vote against this legislation. The Opposition should back up its words with action so that the greatest burden of this Budget, in which there are many inequities, will not have to be borne by those in the community who are least able to cope with that burden.

I remind the Senate that in recent weeks a fairly prominent or, perhaps I should simply say, outspoken member of the Opposition has suggested that pensioners should go to the High Court of Australia if they wish to prevent the deferral of their indexation increases. I suggest that this was a particularly cruel suggestion to have been made by that member of the Liberal Party who was, as everyone knows, Mr Michael Hodgman. It was cruel for a number of reasons. The fact is that in having a deeming provision in the legislation the Government is really compounding the breaking of a promise. It is compounding the breaking of a promise that Mr Hawke made to pensioners in the 1983 election campaign when he promised to reduce the gap between the consumer price index coming out and the increases in pensions which were granted to pensioners and beneficiaries. Essentially, what the Government is doing in these clauses is ignoring the fact that, according to all reports from reputable organisations, including the Australian Council of Social Service, the number of people in poverty has doubled in the past 10 years and is standing now in the vicinity of 2 1/2 million people which includes some 750.000 to 800,000 children.

Notwithstanding the fact that an increasing number of people in the community need all the help that this Government and anybody else can give them, in this legislation we have a series of amendments to the Social Security Act that will increase the poverty, increase the destitution, that a large number of families and individuals are currently in. It is worth pointing out as far as the rent assistance threshold is concerned that a total of over half a million pensioners, unemployment beneficiaries and sickness beneficiaries currently receive rental assistance. By increasing the threshold from $10 to $15 the Government alleges that it will save something over $10m-not a very substantial amount of money, given that the Government has apparently happily paid out to such poverty stricken organisations as the private banking sector and the oil companies in this country in recent months. In attempting to save a little over $10m this Government has been prepared to take an average of approximately $5 from pensioners who are essentially at the mercy of people who make available rental accommodation in the private sector-people who have in the past and presumably in the future will have no compunction about increasing the rate of rental if it suits them to increase their profit margins. This Government is prepared to increase the threshold level from $10 to $15.

I have already pointed out at the second reading stage that the Government's delay of the normal November indexation pension increase from 1 November to 13 December means that pensioners and beneficiaries will essentially have to wait until Christmas Day before they receive the increase in pension that they expected to have from 1 November. In the case of single pensioners that represents in the vicinity of $56 all up. For pensioner couples the amount is around $80. That is not an insignificant amount of money for those people to be deprived of at the time of year when we all traditionally spend more than we normally do. What this Government is saying to pensioners is: `We know that you are hard up. We know that we promised to make your position better. Not only are we not going to honour that promise but we will make it worse for you at Christmas time'.

If the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), who is at the table, thinks that that is sanctimony, I am sorry, but there are a large number of pensioners, and in particular their children, who will suffer, at a time of year when everybody else is benefiting, as a result of what we think is an unconscionable action on the part of this Government simply to save a few million dollars. That amount is nothing in comparison with the amounts of money it has been prepared to fling happily in the direction of a number of organisations in the community that regularly make profits of $1 billion or more. There is no consistency, there is no justice and there is no equity in moving the normal November indexation increases from 1 November to the middle of December. To make the November and May increases permanent increases in December and June simply compounds the problem.

The remaining amendments we are concerned about are set out on pages 33 and 34 of the Bill and encompass Part III. They affect clauses 58 to 60 and we oppose those clauses outright since they are deferring the implementation of legislation that was passed by the Government with a great fanfare some months ago. That was legislation normally known as poverty traps legislation and it was aimed at getting large numbers of people out of the grinding poverty traps in which they frequently find themselves when they rely entirely on social security payments and cannot afford to put themselves into the part time work force because of the damage it does to their welfare payments.

This Government has argued for all the years it has occupied the treasury bench that it is inequitable to have large numbers of women kept out of the work force because child care and job opportunities are not available and because the social welfare system essentially prevents them improving their standard of living and that of their children. The Government introduced the poverty legislation with great enthusiasm and claimed that if it was not exactly the best thing since sliced bread, it came perilously close to it. It was supposed to give significant advantage to large numbers of sole parent families where that sole parent was female-the majority of sole parent families. The poverty traps legislation was aimed, said the Government, at getting those people out of poverty, preventing their getting caught up in traps that kept them in poverty and prevented them from finding their way out and increasing their standard of living of their children and giving them better opportunities economically and socially and in every other way that accrued to people whose standards of living and disposable incomes are at reasonable levels.

Of all the changes that this Bill makes to the Government's existing legislation, I regard the poverty traps amendment as the most obnoxious. I say that because the legislation is so recent and was introduced by this Government as one of the main ways in which it was allegedly keeping the promises that it had made in two election campaigns to an extremely vulnerable, powerless and essentially voiceless group in the community-that is, people in poverty, and particularly those in poverty in families with dependent children. To have backed away from that is unconscionable at the very least and we believe, if it were not unparliamentary to say so, hypocritical at worst.

We would have preferred the Government to have reconsidered its attitude to amending a piece of legislation which it had so recently introduced and passed, with our support, in this place. We were hoping that the concerns expressed by people such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence, the Anglican Mission of St James and St John, the Australian Council of Social Service and an assortment of social welfare groups would not become entrenched in our social fabric. We do not wish to see large numbers of people who are unable to get themselves out of the poverty they have been forced into because of reliance on an inadequate, inappropriate, unjust and inequitable social welfare system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish for a few moments to touch on some matters which reflect on the answer you gave at the end of Question Time in reply to the question I asked of you yesterday. I say, with respect, that I do not believe the information provided to you is a fair reflection of the facts as they occurred on Sunday afternoon. On Sunday afternoon I came to work seeking to enter the only access, to my knowledge, open at that time in Parliament House, the main entrance. My car was prevented from entering in either direction and the car could not be driven down either side of Parliament House. Finally, I alighted from the motor vehicle some considerable distance from Parliament House and had to walk that distance to enter through the main entrance. I did not mind that, but took exception to the fact that that inconvenience, that prohibition, that inhibition was caused by a number of women who, in my view, to the best of my knowledge, illegally and improperly, were obstructing traffic outside Parliament House.
—What about the farmers a couple of months ago? You were not there when the farmers blockaded the airport.
—I have never been obstructed by farmers.
—I was obstructed by farmers and I did not complain.
—Order, Senator Reynolds!

—Thank you, Mr President. It was put to you, Mr President, and you responded in your report, that, as I understand it, the police were protecting and preserving the safety of 500 women. I have to say to you that the only people I saw at threat yesterday, besides modest members such as myself, were the policemen. I would have thought that those 500 women were pretty competent, capable and able to defend and protect themselves. The truth is that there were not 500 women involved; if my memory serves me correctly, there were fewer than six. They were lying on the road, blowing whistles, reading books, cuddling and doing the sorts of things that those types of women do. There was no reason why the policemen-and as I recall there were probably 25 of them-could not have physically picked up those half dozen girls and removed them from the road. There is no practical reason why it was necessary to have a motor-cycle policeman stopping traffic at each end of Parliament House and preventing the free flow of traffic to this building.

SPEECH.PARA: This afternoon, Mr President, you said that your prime responsibility-and I think you said your exclusive responsibility-was to concern yourself with the precincts of Parliament House. With respect, I suggest that there was a hindering of free access to the precincts of Parliament House as a result, not of 500 women misbehaving-at least not on the road; they may have been misbehaving somewhere else-but of no more than six women lying on the road. Those women were capable of being removed, had the police so chosen. To my knowledge, those women had no right and no permission to be there.

This afternoon I interjected when the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) was explaining why the women were there. He asked me why I did not lay a private complaint or charge. Is this Government not only abrogating its responsibilities in respect of the economy and every other part of daily life in Australia but also now abrogating its responsibility for law and order? If I want law and order in this country, can I no longer appeal to the normal processes-the Government and the police? Do I now have to appeal personally as an individual to the courts of this land in order to get into Parliament House and fulfil the functions, duties and responsibilities for which I was elected by the people of Western Australia? It is a very sad day when the only source of relief available to me as a result of the infringement by extreme groups of individuals who collectively share a perverted and distorted view of life is a private complaint.

It may well be that Senator Button believes that anarchy is a social system that he would embrace, accept and believe in, but it is not a due political system, a social value or a legal institution that the vast majority of decent Australians would agree with. There is something terribly wrong-there is a real flaw in this Government-when the Leader of the Government in the Senate, a senior Minister, stands up in this chamber and tells me that if I want free access to my office at Parliament House, I must seek private legal recourse. It is a sad day when the Government no longer takes responsibility, when it is intimidated, it backs off and fails to do anything about six smelly, long haired, orange headed women lying out in the middle of the road. If that factor prevents this Government from functioning, I wonder what else will.

Senator Chaney sought in his own way to give an explanation this afternoon. For my part, I will not be party to any group of people who do more than demonstrate outside, in a normal, civil, legal way. That area across the road from Parliament House is not a camping area, it is an area where there should be peaceful, proper, legal and responsible demonstration. I wonder whether, if any other citizen chose to camp on the lawns opposite Parliament House--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, bring your caravan!

—Or brought a caravan, set up a private loo, cooked and burned on the grass and then, not happy with that, played music like the pied piper and lay in the middle of the road, the traffic would be held up. Would it be like Moses and the Red Sea? If I did that, would the traffic be held back for my benefit so I could lie out there to register some protest or indignation about what is normal, proper or decent about society? I dare say that I would be ignominiously removed and thrown into gaol very quickly. This Government does not have the courage or the fortitude to fulfil its normal moral, social responsibilities. Those who embrace the conduct of those women should be judged alongside them and with them. They can expect nothing less than the same condemnation that those women deserve. For my part, what happened at the weekend and the wimpish response of this Government are fair reflections, fair standards and a fair average of what we can expect from the Government in the future and what we have seen in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in response to a Press article on the dateline service this evening in which Senator Giles has been quoted as saying that a number of the women in the so-called peace camp over the road would make statutory declarations about yesterday's events to set out clearly in a legal framework their reaction to hostility from certain elected members. Having seen Senator Giles on the Willesee program tonight and heard her wimpish response to the activities of these women, I take this opportunity on the adjournment to explain clearly to the Senate exactly what happened yesterday. In the morning two of my colleagues-Senator Vanstone and Senator Newman-and I quite legitimately went over the road to establish the reasons for the demonstration outside Parliament House. We have done this in the past, both collectively and individually, during other demonstrations. However, this time the people out there chose not to speak to us. Why? Because we dared to go over there to their women's space with a man! How disgraceful! A man, nonetheless. We did not seek to provoke any strife. The gentleman who accompanied us was a thorough gentleman and he did not offer comment. In fact, he is an absolute and thorough gentleman.

SPEECH.PARA: We continually asked the women for comment about why they were there. We did not seek publicity. The four of us went out of the Senate side door, around Parliament House, across the road and down to the demonstrators. It was certainly not a case of our seeking publicity. We went quietly across the lawn and then some woman yelled `Mum' which was obviously some kind of code warning the others that there was a man on public land. Suddenly we were surrounded by a bunch of filthy, dirty, smelly women who were quite proud of the fact they they had not showered or changed their clothes for more than a week. If that was not bad enough, they had done the same thing to children and that is what I object to most sincerely. If they want to do that to themselves I suppose that is their business, but they should not be allowed to do it to children. More importantly, I have more respect for myself, my colleagues and staff of this place than to want to see us surrounded within two-inch proximity by these dirty, smelly, foul-mouthed people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You chose to go over there. It was your choice.
—We did not choose to go over there and be surrounded at two-inch proximity, Senator Zakharov, by these dirty, filthy, smelly women.
—You said you went to speak to them.

—You are exactly right, Senator Zakharov. We went to speak to them. When we speak to people we do not normally stand two inches away from them. These people chose not to speak to us. They chose not to tell us why they were demonstrating, other than that they hated men. When we asked why their children were not in school on a school day they refused to answer. When pressed on that matter they stated quite clearly that they would not have their children in school because schools were biased; they taught numbers and letters! Poor little darlings. When they grow up they might be able to add up and to look up a dictionary or a telephone book because they might know their alphabet. We were pushed; we were shoved; we were kicked; we were spat on; we were abused physically and verbally-you name it, we copped it. We did not lay a hand on any one of them and if Senator Giles wants to produce her statutory declarations at some stage, I invite her to do so. More importantly, I invite her to get the people who signed them to take it even further, to make sure that they are not committing perjury, because I guarantee that not one of us laid a hand on them. I wish I could say the same in reverse. A 44-gallon drum of Dettol would not have solved the problem when we got back.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman and I were in a so-called peace tent. That is the only tent we set foot inside. That was an interesting exercise, too, because these people who were there at your expense and mine, at the expense of the Australian taxpayers, had a lovely 26-inch colour television set in this tent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you wouldn't want them to suffer, would you?
—Senator Puplick is quite right. They wanted to look at themselves on television every night and every morning, so that was pretty important.
—Was that the Department of Territories' electricity?

—Senator Vanstone is quite right also. We still cannot get information from the Government as to how those people have access to power-they have access to power because they have special treatment. It was alleged by Senator Giles that we went into other tents. It was alleged by some of those people on radio this morning that I went into tents and kicked children and broke toys. That is absolutely and utterly absurd. There is television footage to justify absolutely and utterly every move we made. We did not-I repeat, did not-lay a hand on any person, male or female. When I say `male', the women do not allow males over the age of seven years. Heaven knows what they do to them then-I shudder to think. We did not lay a hand on one person and we did not go into any tent other than the peace tent. I might add, about 30 seconds after entering the peace tent there was no longer peace, because we got to a stage where we were just constantly abused.

SPEECH.PARA: When I talk about touching people, I suddenly think that I would not be game to touch some of those people over there for the admitted lack of hygiene. As I have said, they simply refuse to shower or to look after their children. One poor little child, about 18 months old, was actually done up with Indian war paint. That poor little kid had not had his or her nose wiped for close to a month, I would say. Quite frankly-I do not wish to be crude-I wonder what happens at the other end. These poor children are really running a severe health risk, along with their so-called mothers.

I would be quite prepared to lay charges against those women over there for the way in which we were treated yesterday, the way in which we were bashed and battered, but I asked them repeatedly for their names and they were smart enough not to give their names. They said: `No, because you will lay charges against us if we give you our names'. They were smart enough to know not to give me their names. When asked point blank, two women refused consistently to give me their names.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could have got their names from the Alice Springs court from Pine Gap.

—That is exactly right. These people are professional demonstrators. Let us not lose sight of the fact that these people are professional demonstrators. They admitted to us and they have admitted on television that they are the same people who went to Pine Gap and Cockburn Sound in my State of Western Australia and created havoc there. Not only did they cause hundreds of thousands of dollars damage to the entrance of the Stirling naval base but also they made assaults on police which were far too disgraceful to describe here. Yet they tried it again and again yesterday. I find it quite amazing to listen to the comments around the place because there is an obvious difference of opinion even among Government senators. Yesterday Senator Coleman privately expressed disgust to me at what had happened. I know that Senator Coleman is a reasonable person.
—Very reasonable.
—She is an extremely reasonable person. I was pleased that she also expressed disgust. Senator Tate said that he was furious at the women's behaviour.
—Do you blame him? They treated him like a tree.
—One cannot blame him. Senator Tate said:

SPEECH.PARA: These people over there are offensive. When I was over there last week one woman took off her pants and marked the territory like a dog.

The point of the matter is that two Government senators have condemned what the women are doing on the lawns in front of Parliament House. I know that other decent Government senators are also in disagreement with what they are doing over there. Yet Senator Reynolds said yesterday, via a notice of motion, that the Senate should pay tribute to the efforts of the women. Is that not lovely? She said that the Senate should pay tribute. Then, of course, Senator Giles appeared on television tonight and said that she is a supporter of the women, that she subscribed to their activities and that she supports their aims and goals. Senator Giles admitted that they are opposed to men, but went on to say that Willesee had used very selective video taping. I think what we are seeing is a division within the Government on this issue. Senator Giles, Senator Reynolds, I believe, and, Senator Zakharov are quite prepared to go over there, stir up trouble and try to get statutory declarations out of people who can barely even talk, let alone write. I will be delighted to see the statutory declarations.

Never before have I or any of my colleagues been confronted by such ghastly behaviour as that which we were confronted with yesterday, morning and afternoon. I think it is important that it be made known to the people of Australia that the so-called peace demonstration is anything but peaceful. It is quite the reverse. It is simply a demonstration against men-a hatred of men. I think this country is one of the most beautiful in the world because men, women and children can live together in harmony. I am very proud to be a woman senator because there is communication between men and women in this place. There is no bias shown between men and women. Yet we have bias out there against men. The display of thuggery and violence by the women is just disgraceful.

The right of access to public land is paramount and men or women should never ignore it. That right of access should never be compromised by a wimpish Government that simply will not take a stand on this matter. The demonstrators are not representative of Australian women; they will never be representative of Australian women. I hope to high heaven that the Government will wake up tomorrow morning and say that it will get rid of them. Mr President, that is the truth of the matter as to what happened when my colleagues and I visited that place yesterday morning and yesterday afternoon.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the matter that was raised by Senator Crichton-Browne in the adjournment debate this evening. The honourable senator spoke as a result of my response this afternoon to his question of yesterday concerning the police action involved in closing a road near Parliament House during a demonstration on Sunday, 19 October. I have to tell Senator Crichton-Browne-I repeat this-that, following his asking of the question, I did have appropriate inquiries made. The information that I provided to him this afternoon was as a result of the advice tendered to me by the Australian Federal Police. The AFP confirmed to me yesterday, after the appropriate inquiries had been made that on a number of occasions on Sunday police diverted traffic away from a section of King George Terrace in the front of Parliament House and said that that action was taken to ensure the safety of a large number of demonstrators. When I asked what they meant by `a large number of demonstrators' the answer was that it was estimated to be about 500. Senator Crichton-Browne said that there were about 600. The Australian Federal Police have told me that there were about 500. They say that about 500 people were performing dance routines in the road and obstructing the flow of traffic. Senator Crichton-Browne has said that, despite their statement that there was no hindrance to access to Parliament House, he had difficulty in getting access and that he had to walk, I think he said, some considerable distance. I just wish to read the last two paragraphs without wearying the Senate of the report that was tendered to me by the Australian Federal Police. It states:

INTERJECT.PARA: On arrival back at Parliament House-
this was some time after 3.15 p.m.-

the demonstrators conducted a dance routine on King George's Terrace. During this period the Terrace was blocked but this did not cause any disruption to any person wishing to enter or leave Parliament House. Whilst this was continuing for some thirty minutes, traffic police were positioned at each end of the Parliament House building to divert any traffic which was not attending at Parliament House. Diversions were only minimal.
The Australian Federal Police, in the last paragraph of their report, said:

Any person who has indicated that he or she could not gain access to Parliament House during this demonstration is not being factual nor has he or she used the necessary initiative required, because the whole front area of Parliament House could have been avoided by using Queen Victoria Terrace even though road works were in progress earlier in the day. Any normal prudent driver, knowing the area could have adopted the latter as a means of avoiding delays.

It is on that basis that I made the statement that the police said that, at no stage, were vehicles prevented from having access to Parliament House. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne would well understand that I, in my position, not having been here on Sunday, have to rely on the advice given to me by the Australian Federal Police who are in charge of the safety areas around the place.

As I understand it, parliamentary precincts are restricted to the line of the present building as well as its front steps. As far as the responsibilities of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate are concerned relating to precincts, that is where our responsibilities begin and that is where they end. If there is any involvement or any demonstrations within those parliamentary precincts then and only then the Speaker of the House of Representatives and I, as the President of the Senate, are responsible and can take action. We can also take action if in any way senators and members are impeded in their access to or egress from the building but, on this occasion the police have given us the assurance that, as far as they are concerned, there was no difficulty in people gaining access to the building during the course of the demonstrations. Whatever honourable senators or I might think of the camp that has been established on the lawns in front of Parliament House, I say to the Senate and to the Parliament that, because it is not within the precincts of the Parliament, it is not the responsibility of the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, let me say at the outset-I said this at the outset the last time I spoke-that I was not in any way reflecting upon you or on the fact that you had presented other than the facts that had been provided to you by somebody else. I again want to make that fundamentally clear. As you made clear when you answered my question at the end of Question Time today, you said: `On the report, the evidence and the information that has been provided to me, this is the situation'. I understood that and when I responded this evening I again made it clear that I was taking issue not with you, Mr President, but with the information which was provided to you. I say to you again that you were not provided with accurate information. I do not want to compromise anybody else, but I came in a Commonwealth car and the driver could not get me in. We went round the building on a number of occasions. Ultimately when I did alight I did so at the main entrance of Parliament House. I approached a policeman, whom I will not name because he will be easily identified, and I asked him why he had not picked up the six-only six-offenders who were lying in the road in a very relaxed form. From a distance one could have observed them to be under the influence of alcohol or drugs-I am not sure which-as their movements seemed to be rather disjointed. The policeman responded to me that he had instructions from the inspector in charge who was not, as I understand it, present at the time. I reiterate that there were not 500 singing, dancing or chanting; there were but six lying in the middle of the road. The balance of the alleged five hundred were way removed, steeped in their tents or sitting on the steps some considerable distance from the road. It would have been a simple process to remove them. I got the impression, and nothing else, that he was rather frustrated that he was not able to pick them up with the policemen he had with him, who seemed to outnumber the offenders three to one, and remove them accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the situation. I repeat: I had difficulty entering and the road had been blocked off by five or six women. I find it regrettable that sufficient action could not have been taken to remove that number of protesters. The only danger that they were subject to was the danger they were imposing upon themselves by lying in the middle of a busy road. I would have thought that under normal circumstances anyone lying in the middle of a busy road would have been endangering himself. I find it a rather cute, curt and peculiar process of law that the police stop the traffic to save people from being hurt. I would have thought that under normal circumstances they would have removed the people so that the traffic did not get hurt.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you couldn't get in the side door-it was locked.

—I sought to make the point earlier that I could not enter the Parliament from either side because under those circumstances only the main entrance was available. With respect, I repeat that which I put to you previously. I have been precise and I intended, on the occasion that I had this difficulty, to record the facts before the Senate, so I took some very considerable care to ensure that in a dispassionate way I observed precisely the circumstances and the events that took place at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Could the Minister for Defence advise details of his Department's use of the Cardwell Range for jungle training exercises.
(2) How much land is reserved for this purpose.
(3) How frequently are exercises scheduled in the Cardwell Range.
(4) How many soldiers were involved in these exercises in 1985.
(5) How many support vehicles were required to travel in this area during 1986.
(6) Is the Department of Defence planning to increase jungle training exercises in future years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) Cardwell Range is not used by Defence for conducting jungle training exercises.

(5) Although the Cardwell Range is not used for jungle training the Army's Field Force Battle School (FFBS) is located south east of the Range. The FFBS which trains soldiers in jungle warfare techniques utilises Commonwealth and leased land totalling 11,653 ha. This area extends north of the FFBS to the east and north east of Cardwell Range. Occasionally, and always with a permit issued from the State Forestry Office, the Cardwell Range forestry area is used for transit to FFBS exercise areas.
(6) Defence does not foresee any increase in the level of jungle training than that being presently conducted.
